movie_review_blurb: It is easy to see why Greg Kinnear always looks like he has a tear in his eye. Presumably this movie bored him to tears.
This film oversimplifies the concept of unrequited love, and over-romanticizes the notion of everlasting love.
What happened to Lucky McKee?
Edwards makes the leap to the majors with confidence, adapting his grounded approach to sci-fi to a much larger scale.
Neighbors is a bit of a mess, neither outrageous nor thoughtful enough to compensate for its lack of narrative imagination. But the film is also not without its modest pleasures.
For Swingers fans, seeing Favreau make something small again might be worth it-even if the results are more appetizing in theory than in execution.
The Quiet Ones is a pretty ironic title for a horror film whose primary scare tactic is to periodically crank up the volume, sending the needle to the red with a sudden spike in the decibel levels.
Even at a hefty 142 minutes, The Amazing Spider-Man 2 hasn't the time for its surfeit of plot, nor for the sprawling ensemble of supporting characters caught in the sticky web Webb weaves.
Locke, as fascinating as it is in theory, never evolves into anything more than a glorified acting exercise.
Blue Ruin is as visually striking as one might expect a film helmed by a talented cinematographer to be. But Saulnier has more than a great eye; he's got the soul of a natural filmmaker ...

Proxy's greatest attribute is its deliberate dismantling of the audience's assumptions. Writer-director Zack Parker has made a genre whatsit whose central mystery lies in the stealth motivations of its characters.
The film rages, dully and impotently, against a future that has more or less already arrived.
Along the way, The Railway Man accumulates some power and insight, but it's also hard to shake the feeling that a complicated first-person account has been given the Weinstein treatment.
Laying eyes on the film's piles upon piles of valuable junk-old recording equipment, leather-bound novels, cosmetic clutter-is a bit like rummaging through the director's attic.
Oculus doesn't exactly shatter the clichés of the genre, but it does distort them in a couple of interesting ways, beginning with a creative reversal of the usual vengeful-spirit plot ...
What's commendable about Cage's performance, given his usual tendency to go as far over the top as possible, is the way the actor downplays even the occasional surge of violent emotion.
Under The Skin lets its nightmarish imagery do the talking, forgoing explanation in favor of total sensory immersion.
"Unpredictable" is one of the highest compliments one can pay a movie, especially an American thriller.
He may be seriously slumming by putting a modern spin on 1972's The Legend Of Boggy Creek, but at least Goldthwait's done his homework.
If nothing else, Obvious Child proves that rom-com conventions require no apologies, at least when they're invested with honesty and sharp humor. Also, a few fart jokes never hurt.
The Fault In Our Stars is a snappy and resonant teenage weepie, blessed with sparks of wit and buoyed by the talents of a charismatic cast.
The major problem here is that Braff seems completely incapable of distinguishing between pathos and bathos.
It's nice to look at, easy to watch, and impossible to remember for the length of a car-ride home.
A broody and reasonably entertaining act of brand extension, marred mainly by its limited license to do anything but inch audiences a little closer to the inevitable ape-slavement.
movie_title: Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes (2014)

movie_review_blurb: There's never been a movie quite like Boyhood, and it may be years before anyone works up the gumption to match its achievement.
Few will get through the film not feeling as though they know and understand the author a little better, a little more deeply, a little more intimately.
Deliver Us From Evil doesn't even believe in its tropes, whose moldiness no veneer of "authenticity" can mask.
McCarthy is going to need better material if she's going to transition into a rom-com career.
The journalism is comprehensive, the scope admirably large. Those who can keep up will learn plenty about how a major, high-profile case proceeds.
movie_title: Whitey: United States of America v. James J. Bulger (2014)

movie_review_blurb: An enthusiastically zany comedy, made in the reality-bending tradition of a Zucker, Abrahams, and Zucker production.
The director navigates an enclosed space with cinematic flair, his dynamic camerawork assuring that the talky proceedings never feel especially "stagy."
Haggis has tackled his own penchant for heavy-handedness with a typically heavy hand. Those who groaned through Crash will find plenty to groan about here, too.
An uncommonly clever genre movie, reliant not on special effects-of which there are basically none-but on heavy doses of paranoia.
Strong sci-fi grapples with its premise instead of concealing it.
A bleaker, less colorful descendant of the Mad Max films, replacing the rollicking action of that franchise with a mood of nihilistic despair.
There aren't just more dragons, but more characters, more plot, more everything. The trade-off is that the charm of the original gets a little lost, a casualty of rapid-franchise expansion.

In this spectacularly entertaining sequel, Rogers is still running, jumping, and chucking his mighty shield like it's 1945. But now he's doing so with the weariness and distrust of historical hindsight.
At its best, the film gets by on its striking imagery, from a panorama of sickening human decadence to a mid-movie retelling of the creation story that might make Terrence Malick weep.
The problem with Cesar Chavez is that it inches steadily away from a down-to-earth portrayal of its subject, eventually placing him on the very kind of pedestal he never sought to occupy.
Nymphomaniac may at best be a digression, but it's not one of Von Trier's weaker ones.
When getting into the nitty-gritty of tapes and tracks, Grohl makes a strong case for music docs directed by musicians.
American Hustle turns out to be a freewheeling party of a movie, one that never stops adding complications and wrinkles and hungry new players to the mix.

The irony of Saving Mr. Banks is that it takes this true story of Hollywood conflict, of artistic integrity pitted against studio moxie, and gives it the same warm-and-fuzzy treatment the company gave Poppins.
There's nothing like a fire-breathing dragon to inject some heat back into a franchise gone lukewarm.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Twenty-some years after Barton Fink, the Coens have returned with another comedy about the maddening, exasperating business of trying to make art for money. The joke is still on the artist, but the brothers aren't laughing so hard this time around.
Out Of The Furnace turns out to be a predictable, very ordinary retribution story, propped up by slumming A-listers and a gritty veneer of Rust Belt desperation.
The very qualities that make the man such a revered figure-his selfless devotion to change, his unfailing moral rectitude-also make him a pretty dull subject for a movie.
Lending real gravity to his character's single-minded crusade, [Brolin is] the best reason to give the film a chance.
More accustomed to slinging insults than beaming with paternal pride, [Vaughn] makes sincerity look as uncomfortable as constipation. "Feel-good" does not come easily for the guy.

Like too many franchise installments, Catching Fire builds to more of an ellipsis than a period, teasing the next chapter instead of providing closure. But isn't that true of The Empire Strikes Back as well?
Should any non-converted souls manage to stumble into Dear Mr. Watterson, the onscreen samples should be enough to stoke their curiosity.
As an ode to fading small towns, and to the state its director once called home, it feels downright disingenuous.
Fans won't learn much from it that they didn't already know.
Death creeps into the movie, like an invisible wave of radiation from a detonated nuke, and some of the imagery owes more to Cormac McCarthy than to Stephenie Meyer.
As is the case with most good superhero sequels, The Dark World escapes the oppressive duty of franchise building, finally getting to play in the world its origin-story predecessor established.
It's a melancholy comic fable about the here and now, thinly disguised as an outlandish vision of the there and later.
Mood Indigo plays like some extreme behavioral experiment, an attempt to determine just how much whimsy, exactly, an audience can endure.
Not only saddles its prehistoric attractions with sassy banter, but also inserts them into an impossibly generic coming-of-age adventure.

For all his directorial shortcomings, Berg has a knack for capturing men at work; his depiction of special-ops maneuvering -- of silently casing the enemy base, of planning the attack -- is as compelling as the chaotic violence he orchestrates later.
It's easy to be seduced by the loosely observational vibe of the movie, even as its tale of a shrinking violet struggling not to be a late bloomer fails to strike more than a single note of dismay.

With sober eloquence, the filmmaker lays out the arrival of the Khmer Rouge, the philosophy used to justify their crimes, and the slow slipping away of his family, each member claimed by this horrible social experiment.
As a nostalgia trip, and a valentine to the virtues of its terrific source material, Veronica Mars gets the job done.
Even when Bad Words is bad in the wrong way, it tends to be bad in the right way, too.
Anderson has made a madcap caper that doubles as a winsome eulogy for such archaic virtues as glamour, civility, and dutiful customer service.
After a stage-setting opening passage, director Robert May cuts deeper-past the allegations of wrongdoing, to a more multi-faceted critique of the justice system.
3 Days To Kill is one Liam Neeson shy of a Liam Neeson vehicle.
There's something depressingly schematic about the way director Babak Najafi, replacing prior helmsman Daniel Espinosa, crosscuts among the mad scrambles of his down-on-their-luck protagonists.
The dialogue has the flavor of 2014, even as these paramours simply borrow the dating wisdom -- and gender politics -- of their 1980s counterparts.
Slightly squarer and less subversive than the other one, but also admirable in its refusal to simply replicate the circuitry of a blockbuster predecessor.
The Monuments Men feels not just self-conscious but also a bit self-congratulatory, its creator squashing the spirit of adventure with too many grandiose lines about the Importance Of Art.
It's a mostly colorless weepie, aiming for the mythic power of a Great American Novel, but achieving dramatic vagueness instead.
Its points about the misplacement of blame, and the morality of fitting punishment to crime, are never less than trenchant.
The Banshee Chapter can't seem to decide if it wants to be a found-footage horror movie, or a more traditional one. To its detriment, it splits the difference.
Whereas the other Paranormal films rely on an escalation of terrors, The Marked Ones is characterized by long stretches of mundanity, occasionally interrupted by a cheap shock.
At three hours, The Wolf Of Wall Street is Scorsese's longest movie (barely edging out Casino). It's also his crassest, his loudest, maybe his funniest.
I Origins is an exercise in supreme obviousness, beginning (but not ending) with its double entendre of a title.
Corbijn handles this surfeit of plot with ease, skillfully preserving the mystery of Issa's motives and creating an atmosphere of pervasive distrust.
Turns out the galaxy far, far away is a pretty boring place to visit without someone around to roll his eyes, put the moves on royalty, and demand to get paid.
A sequel as desperate, in its own "official" way, as the knockoff-brand origin story that previously besmirched the franchise name.
Within this vacuum of malaise, fine performers struggle valiantly to breathe life into their roles.
Laggies is undone by the sitcom contrivance of its scenario and some very on-the-nose dialogue, which keeps reminding viewers that, yes, this is a story about willful regression.
For Michael Keaton, Birdman is some kind of gift from the movie gods, a license to have his cake and messily devour it too.
If Dear White People is Simien's School Daze, complete with academic setting and DIY scrappiness, does that mean he has a Do The Right Thing in him, too?
More Full Metal Jacket than Dead Poet's Society, the film is an epic battle of wills between two fanatical artists, one doing everything in his power to painfully make a master out of the other.
Moss uncovers something greater than a vision of a divided community; he's made a drama as prickly and surprising as any fictional character study.
Neither the Dracula we need nor the one we deserve.
It's genuinely nice to see a man of Terry's stature put his faith in an artist of a younger generation, their bond strengthened by a shared love of music.

This Left Behind may be worse than the last Left Behind, but it's much less boring, thanks in part to the commitment of its star, who plays the often ludicrous material with the straightest of faces. The Cage works in mysterious ways.

Billed as a spin-off of The Conjuring, the film operates more like a shoddy brand extension; it cost five times less than its predecessor, and the slashed budget shows-both in the economy casting and in the over-lit, sometimes hideous digital imagery.
In an age when most cartoon companies have traded pens for pixels, the magicians at Laika continue to create fantastically elaborate universes out of pure elbow grease.
What possibly could have possessed a comedian as sharp as Simon Pegg to squander his gifts on a movie as soggy as Hector And The Search For Happiness?
movie_title: Hector And The Search For Happiness (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The Maze Runner bucks the conventions of its genre by functioning as a pure cliffhanger machine, fueled by mystery instead of melodrama.
Dumb fun is rarely this smartly delivered.
A sequel so slapdash and ineffectual that its army of directors-six of them total, counting the poor sucker whose contribution got axed-might well be accused of intentionally burying the franchise.
Not My Type is a modest triumph, but a triumph nonetheless.
The stealth highlight of this franchise has always been the flavorful cultural satire, which takes center stage throughout much of Mockingjay's fleet runtime.

The atmosphere is mythic and pervasive. The imagery, of night and nature and dancing flames, seems ripped from liner notes. Even the title sounds like something you might see scrawled across a record sleeve in Gothic typeface.
movie_title: A Spell To Ward Off The Darkness (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The Voices wants it all ways at once, and while its severe shifts in tone are certainly bold (and intentional), they also prevent the film from properly functioning under any genre umbrella.
The ugly spectacle of college kids stripping other college kids naked, in a humiliating show of dominance, speaks disturbing volumes.
Binder, who once made lowbrow comedies but now specializes in middlebrow dramedies, is in several leagues over his head with this story ...
Though the characters are at odds, the cast operates in perfect unison.
Not since Wild Hogs, perhaps, has a comedy so repeatedly insisted that there's nothing funnier than the thought of two men touching each other.
Predestination just wants to blow minds. But in its best moments, the ones that put Snook front and center, it threatens to break hearts instead.
For those who have ever nursed suspicions that the answer is "not enough," Honeymoon will inspire chills much more bone-deep than the ones provoked by, say, some poltergeist flinging around chairs.

Nestled within its sins-of-the-elders narrative is a faintly charming cross-generational bonding picture, pairing a worldly cynic with a young girl taking her last gasp of secular air before giving her life to the Lord.
As cinema, Selma is commendable; as cultural barometer, it's beyond reproach.
Big Eyes has plenty of surface pleasures, but there was reason to expect more than that from it.
Two Days, One Night is a small miracle of a movie, a drama so purely humane that it makes most attempts at audience uplift look crass and calculated by comparison.

Blackjack is more of a noose than a needle for this self-destructive blowhard, and if that sounds less dramatic than the tale of a man who just can't walk away from the table, it is significantly funnier.
A portrait of the artist as visionary oddball, for whom life was an endless source of both beauty and the irritating distractions blocking his view of said beauty.
All this plot unfolds like obligation, a paragraph of book-report summary bulked up to feature length.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The structural gamesmanship is just a smokescreen, a way to obfuscate the pulp nature of what is, ultimately, little more than a glorified, low-aiming potboiler.
What really distinguishes The Babadook, however, is the metaphorical potency of its narrative.
Somehow unsentimental in his sentimentality, Nighy makes shopworn carpe diem platitudes sound like fresh wisdom.

The director's modus operandi-static, meticulously arranged long takes, shot in deep focus to use background and foreground space-is so entirely unique that it's impossible to not to get some joy out of just gawking at his films.
movie_title: A Pigeon Sat on a Branch Reflecting on Existence (2015)

movie_review_blurb: It's grisly, darkly comic stuff.
What Shim needed was a steady escalation of tension, as well as characters a little easier to connect to.
An intimate epic to sink into; it uses the unchanging age of its actors, whose characters stubbornly resist changing for two decades, as a melancholy commentary on the maturation process.
An ingeniously plotted and rather heartbreaking movie ...
Lehane adapted The Drop from one of his own short stories, and it has the feel of a modest yarn stretched uncomfortably to feature length.
[It] deflects criticism, its leads working hard to win folks over. Like Maggie, audiences may be powerless to resist.
The filmmaker observes with great sensitivity, letting certain conflicts play just below the surface.
A real turducken of a teen movie, If I Stay stuffs a tale of budding musicianship into a banal romance and then stuffs that combination into a maudlin supernatural melodrama.

The movie would rather play a tiny violin for its subjects-perhaps literally, given the gratingly manipulative score-than objectively untangle the legality of what one talking head dubiously describes as its "brilliant story."
This major influence on today's new class of dystopian YA smashes now looks like just another greedy knockoff on-screen -- a monochromatic Divergent, or something similar.
What chutzpah it takes to hire one of the world's most recognizable movie stars and then render him completely unrecognizable.

At times, the movie seems to exist for no other purpose than to collide these two personalities together, privileging their antagonistic banter above all else. But isn't that the basic point of all buddy comedies?

What the new Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles lacks is not fidelity, but a spirit of genuine boyish fun -- the sense that anyone involved saw more than a very specific shade of green in the freshly digital scales of these 30-year-old characters.
For a film that champions the transcendent power of spice, The Hundred-Foot Journey is awfully bland.
The movie exists mainly as an act of social advocacy, showing how one portion of the population lives and offering a sobering rebuke to pull-yourself-up-by-your-bootstraps rhetoric.
What's at stake here, in this grim and grimly comic story, is how a man of God will face his fate.
Overwritten and un-cinematic ...
The humor is questionably intentional, and the deck is so thoroughly stacked against the heroine that it's impossible to take the thing seriously as a vision of hardship.
The movie is dull right up until the point that it becomes completely, characteristically bonkers, with Miike trotting out some of his trademark obscene violence.
Something of a slog, in no small part because it casts Richard Gere, of all actors, as a drunken vagrant.
Swedish director Ruben Östlund's damning, frequently hilarious study of imploding male ego.
The Humbling is interesting only in how it fits into the filmography of its major talents.
First and foremost, the film is a showcase for its wiry and wired star, and for the fascinatingly amoral anti-hero he brings to life.
Green demonstrates no control over his star, who dodders through the movie in a sleepy daze.
Mostly, I connected to its gentle melancholy, the sense of a life changing in almost imperceptible ways.
Both an oral history and a lament for a neighborhood whose young women-some hookers, some not-went unprotected and un-avenged by L.A. law enforcement for decades.
Some stories are worth getting misty-eyed about, and some crowd-pleasers really please.
A great cast is a terrible thing to waste.
movie_title: This Is Where I Leave You (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Baumbach is never less than shrewd in the way he links his protagonists through insecurity.
Burgundy is heavy with feeling.

Goodnight Mommy plays on the nerves with expert cruelty-so much so, actually, that by the time the film belatedly comes clean about the plot secret everyone has already guessed, you're too pummeled into submission to care.
Tusk grew out of a podcast joke, and it shows: There's a making-it-up-as-we-go-along quality to the movie, which seems too satisfied with its own nuttiness to be truly transgressive.
As entertainment, The Equalizer rarely delivers: It's like a superhero origin story invested with half-assed gravitas.
Heavy on speeches and light on actual drama.
Streamlines a fascinating true story into functional prestige filmmaking, but it's still plenty engaging, thanks largely to its lead.
Heaven Knows What quickly obtains an oddly charming rhythm, a sense of eavesdropping on sometimes unlikable, but fully realized, social outsiders.
One of the director's most pitiless visions-a drama as pitch black as the night that envelops its characters.

While the director takes care to show how Adèle struggles with social pressure, hiding her sexuality from her friends and parents, that aspect never hijacks the narrative. This is a drama of self-discovery, not a social-issues film.

No amount of needless chatter can quite dilute the power of The Counselor's grim endgame, especially given the way its writer and director conspire to keep the threat offscreen, like some terrible, unseen force of nature.
The real problem with 21 and Over is that it swipes most of its material from better movies.
If we must have supernatural high-school romances, can they all be as relatively painless as Beautiful Creatures?
Director John Moore, the anonymous hack at the helm, stages car chases and gun fights with messy imprecision.
movie_title: A Good Day To Die Hard (2013)

movie_review_blurb: More arch than amusing, John Dies at the End may exhaust your patience for everything-but-the-kitchen-sink "storytelling." Still, there's something endearing about its relentless barrage of gonzo happenings.
Good luck ascribing a clear satirical agenda to Jonathan Levine's tonally uneven zomcom, which suffers an identity crisis nearly as severe as its protagonist's.
The new film is largely a recap of the older ones, with more celebrity testimonials and fewer Metallica songs but little fresh insight into the miscarriage of justice it chronicles.
You know a fright-flick craze is in danger of running its course when Marlon Wayans comes along to broadly, belatedly spoof it.
A political thriller that's never quite as smart as you wish it were.
Even if one grows impatient with the film's dovetailing tales of small-town desperation, it's hard to tire of its visual execution.
A shallow, star-studded amalgam of every Los Angeles cops-and-crooks drama you've ever seen.
When making a sequel to a beloved genre classic, it's generally unwise to include clips of the masterpiece you're attempting to live up to.
The most brutally honest picture ever made about growing old and wasting away.
For fans of Ursula Meier's last movie, the strikingly offbeat domestic drama Home, this act of auteur-on-auteur emulation may feel like a comedown. Yet it's still stirring work.
Want more from a late-summer joyride than slides, wheelies and bunny hops? Get a load of Shannon, dementedly inspired, trying out an oddball accent and Richard Widmark giggle.
A fiendishly clever genre Rubik's Cube that demonstrates, if nothing else, how much Fangoria fare benefits from the wicked wit of a real writer.
You may be dazzled or exasperated by this flurry of stylistic excess. You probably won't be bored.
No amount of strong acting, however, can entirely compensate for the dramatic conveniences or every shrill appearance by Jane's cartoonishly despicable roommates.
Stirring as a celebration of voter empowerment, No may also inspire pangs of wistful nostalgia.
The problem with the film, which somewhat inexplicably won the Golden Bear at Berlin last year, is that it scarcely transcends the basic novelty of its premise.
[Burshtein has] reinvigorated a familiar narrative by painting it against an unfamiliar backdrop.
Those looking for a summary of the WikiLeaks phenomenon-from the big leaks to the major shifts in public perception about Assange and his cause-won't find a more cleanly delineated version.
movie_title: We Steal Secrets: The Story Of Wikileaks (2013)

movie_review_blurb: In the process of justifying its own existence, Before Midnight redeems the very notion of sequels.
There is ... no hangover in The Hangover Part III. And yet a sense of creative dehydration still pervades.
Rip-roaring set-pieces aside, the biggest pleasure here is still the yin-yang chemistry between Kirk and Spock, even as the writers sand down the barbed edges of the characters' interactions.
It's like a dour, less stylized version of one of the violent revenge fantasies from Kim's fellow countryman, Park Chan-wook.
It sets up this distaff-Deliverance scenario much better than it pays it off.
Most fatally, No One Lives neglects to provide a rooting interest. Great horror movies engender sympathy for the lambs being led to the slaughter.
An investigative mystery, a real-life soap opera, and-most compellingly, perhaps-a searching "interrogation" (the director's word) of the hows and whys of storytelling itself.
The film often plays like a nostalgic doodle, gliding aimlessly from one classic-rock-scored encounter to another. But then, that meandering quality is part of the appeal ...
It's hard not to wish Downey were sparring with his costumed comrades again, instead of trading barbs with the far-less-colorful cast members-old and new-of this busy, sporadically diverting sequel.
What strikes you aren't just the iconic moments, but the little ones.
Cusack and Akerman scramble down a series of dimly lit, identical-looking passageways. The setting is as ill-defined as the characters.
Whether it's memoir or personalized fiction, Ginger & Rosa displays a shrewd understanding of late adolescence-a time when every emotional slight lands like an atom bomb.
The latest advances in computer animation have been applied to a truly primitive comedy-Ice Age recast with a family of nattering Neanderthals.
Thank goodness for Fey, who lends this sitcom soap a credible emotional center.

Nancy, Please hasn't much to offer beyond the amusing spectacle of a complacent college boy losing his cool. But that may be enough, especially for those who've sparred with archrivals of their own -- real or invented.
A disarmingly sweet descendant of the blood-on-the-ice classic Slap Shot.
Plague offers an instructive lesson for Occupy-era rabble-rousers: Only when coupled with a knowledge base will your sound and fury signify anything.
What's truly marvelous about the stop-motion fantasia ParaNorman is the way it acknowledges adolescence as a daily horror show.
Unforgivable is a bit too relaxed to function as a thriller. Though admirably unpredictable, its plot is also spread thin among these fickle lovers.
The problem with Celeste and Jesse Forever is that it inserts these two believable characters-and their credible conflict-into a rather lazy and conventional romantic comedy.
Aaron Cross immediately registers as a more vulnerable and sympathetic protagonist than his predecessor.
William Friedkin, that old '70s genre pro, seems reinvigorated by this cast of amoral schemers and their seedy stomping grounds.
You know Chandrasekhar is half-invested when even a montage of blows to the crotch (with each hit a potential cause of our hero's "lazy sperm") feels completely phoned in.
More exciting than Verhoeven fans might expect, Wiseman's Total reboot won't betray your fond memories of its iconic predecessor.
Twentysomething caped-crusader fans may get a warmer buzz of nostalgia here than they will at The Dark Knight Rises.
The plot is pure boilerplate, yet the draw of this franchise has always been its fancy footwork, and the movie's stuttering, herky-jerky spectacles of impassioned movement are pretty extraordinary.
Dano, in his best performance since There Will Be Blood, offers a bravely unflattering depiction of beta-male possessiveness.
The writer-director-star still hasn't learned to smoothly blend broad comedy and family-values sermonizing.
The high concept breeds lowbrow gags.
Trusting an action drone like Worthington to anchor the human drama is a fatal mistake.
Quote not available.

Part of the film's pleasure lies in watching its spirit of poky Southern amiability give way to true-crime insanity.
By the time a grizzled Jeremy Irons saunters in, ready to dole out a comeuppance, perceptive viewers will have mentally flipped to the last page.
Shockingly uneventful, this horror film marks time until dropping its big, dumb reveal.
movie_title: House at the End of the Street (2012)

movie_review_blurb: It's hard to say what's worse: the sneering disdain for modern child-rearing tactics or the hacky generation-clash humor.
A sentimental slog that encourages us to celebrate the survival of European tourists while turning a blind eye to the deaths of thousands of others.
What lingers are the stormy tête-à-têtes between Rudd and Mann -- a couple with whom we'd gladly celebrate the big 4-0.
To gaze upon the film, like Frodo staring into that prophetic magic orb, is to be shaken by a dark vision of cinema's future.

Most admirably, Life of Pi resists turning its remarkably realistic, digitally created feline into a friend or pet.
A True Hollywood Story so cheeky and thin it makes My Week with Marilyn seem substantial.
Bestiaire accommodates multiple readings, allowing its audience to project theories about spectatorship and captivity onto its silent beasts of burden.
Adjust to the Oscar winner's deadpan cartoon impersonation, and you may get on the wavelength of this quirkfest.
The conceptual gimmickry eclipses everything else, including a typically sharp script from Tom Stoppard and the earnest efforts of well-dressed Brits playing well-dressed Russians.
A relationship drama as radically bifurcated as Tropical Malady and as trenchantly insightful as Everyone Else.
Some day, an editor is going to put together a highlight reel of Denis Lavant's greatest performances. Will most of it be scenes from Holy Motors?
Basically a three-hour montage, Cloud Atlas neutralizes involvement in its dovetailing dramas by treating every character as a point in some quasi-spiritual game of connect-the-dots.

Squint hard enough and it's possible to see the sharper, more inspired comedy David O. Russell might have made out of Accidental Love.
Moving so quickly its flaws barely register -- the blockbuster equivalent of sleight-of-hand -- Now You See Me fares best when simply relying on the no-illusions chemistry between its leads.

Works much better as an act of earnest education than as, well, comedy or drama.
As in many Leonard narratives, the plot is largely just an excuse to put these big talkers in a room or on a telephone line together.
Another misfire starring its director, Tom At The Farm is the first real folly from young French-Canadian director Xavier Dolan.

There's still something undeniably moving about the film's trajectory, which allows McConaughey to blossom into an empathetic figure-one whose homophobia fades as his fighting spirit intensifies-without losing his rapscallion spirit.

Tsai's latest is small and human and primal-a howl from the gutter, and a survival story about life on the fringe, in which a family of four ekes out an existence one day and scavenged meal at a time.
In any case, the crowd I watched it with sat in awed, tense silence throughout-a mighty good sign that a thriller is doing its job.
Another of the director's intimate portraits of people living on the fringes of society, it's at once her most plot-heavy and pedigreed production, and one of her most oblique.
A repetitive but sometimes beguiling documentary produced by the directors of Leviathan,
Becomes a little numbing. Until then, however-and breaking points will vary-it feels like the most visually dazzling film of the fest
movie_title: The Strange Color of Your Body's Tears (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The actors are both superb, conveying suppressed feeling through falters in their perpetual poker faces.
West essentially re-creates a real-life atrocity, beat for awful beat, for the sake of some second-rate thrills.

That's a fairly contrived sitcom scenario, but Holofcener bends it into a loose, lightly funny meditation on divorce, getting older, and impending empty-nest syndrome. Also, yes, Gandolfini is terrific.
Only those unversed in frothy, Weinstein-approved confections will wonder where Populaire is headed.
The results are akin to seeing the Nixon presidency through the eyes of his top aides; it's as much a portrait of innocence lost as a behind-closed-doors exposé.
Here and there, the faintest glimmer of actual drama presents itself.
There are some who have complained that C.O.G. ends too abruptly, but it has the bracing, devastating punctuation of a fine short story.
Closed Circuit may be little more than a high-minded, shrewdly topical gloss on a shopworn genre, but its cynicism is bracing.
Narrowness of focus keeps the movie from becoming bloated with self-importance, but it also leaves it feeling a little inconsequential-more of a pleasing snack than a satisfying meal.
Through The Never plays like The Black Album of concert films: It's enormous, slick, and occasionally rousing, but largely fails to capture the sheer intensity of Metallica's superior '80s work.
Buying that this girl would have trouble making friends, or snagging a genuine date to the dance, is even harder than pretending that a pair of glasses makes Rachael Leigh Cook look undesirable.
Paradise boasts the broadest, most saccharine tendencies of its writer and first-time director. In Cody terms, it's a doodle that can't be undid.
The saving grace of Kill Your Darlings is its sordid romantic angle, a narrative thread that pulls the film away from wink-wink allusions and into more serious emotional territory.
Channeling the evils of human bondage through the experiences of one weary figure, McQueen has constructed another intensely physical character study about a man trapped in his own flesh.

Those who demand pure objectivity from their documentaries may stumble on God Loves Uganda, which never pretends to be impartial, probably because it's next to impossible to do so when tackling this topic.
A barbed indie character study that seems perched, like Big Fan, between dark humor and probing psychodrama.
A sporadically amusing farce with a great gimmick.
It's [Hanks'] best performance in years, one that resurrects the actor's dormant gift-shared by Hollywood ancestors like Gregory Peck and Jimmy Stewart-for charismatic decency.
Runner Runner is a run-of-the-mill rise-and-fall story, treating its hero to fabulous, exotic luxury before tugging the rug out from under him.
Drenched in the evening glow of its urban and suburban backdrops, Darker comes alive in the dark, when its characters are drowning their sorrows in song, the sauce, or conversation.
The movie builds repeatedly to crescendo, pushing some desperate individual to the brink and then watching as he or she explodes into violence.
It's too broad to qualify as incisive, too mild to rise above the level of amusing.
If nothing else, Gravity makes the case for throwing immense resources at true visionaries; the blockbuster craftsman as adventurer, Cuarón expertly blends the epic with the intimate.

As easy as it is to be intellectually seduced by the man's arguments, it's also hard to avoid wishing that his own cult of personality-his jokes and his history-didn't dominate so much of the running time.

On page and screen, Gordon-Levitt mostly fails to transform his bulky title protagonist into a multi-dimensional figure. He belongs in the final 15 minutes of an SNL episode, not at the center of a full-sized comedy.
Like too many sequels, this second helping of Meatballs confuses bigger for better, piling on the action but misplacing much of the original's charm.
movie_title: Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs 2 (2013)

movie_review_blurb: The East deftly mixes spy-movie pleasures with headier concerns.
More than anything Wong has ever made, the movie chokes on exposition, its more poetic concerns stifled by its surfeit of plot.
Far from pining for their glory days, Wright and company are living them now. The World's End looks, despite its title, like just the beginning for all involved.
The film gains a ramshackle quality that's difficult to resist.

Well intentioned and reasonably well constructed, Fruitvale Station seems to exist for the sole purpose of making what should be an obvious point: Oscar Grant didn't deserve to die, and the officer who shot him in the back had no right to do so.
Imagine for a moment what someone like Roman Polanski could do with such a loaded nightmare scenario. And then marvel at how thoroughly it's wasted in this threadbare throwaway ...
Labors under the delusion that all filmmakers need to engineer a crowd-pleaser are a collection of tried-and-true conventions and a healthy dose of nostalgia.
A sequel was a foregone conclusion, but how did those responsible lose sight of what made the original special?
A nearly three-hour epic, a melodrama writ large, and blessed with a young man's ambition.
Jordan, a master of mood, creates an unsettling atmosphere of small-town despair, and the film's sporadic spikes of violence ... are often inventive.
World War Z bucks the current trend in summer blockbusters by feeling weirdly understuffed. It's an episodic adventure without enough episodes.

For all its sporadic flashes of insight, Unfinished Song is built around the assumption that there's nothing funnier than old timers throwing devil horns, doing the robot, or performing a rousing rendition of Salt-N-Pepa's "Let's Talk About Sex."
If it's possible to be both impressed and appalled by a movie's pull-no-punches savagery, Maniac earns that dubious distinction.
A gentle, poky riff on college-comedy clichés, complete with a villainous, snobbish fraternity, a heroic, outcast fraternity, and a stuffy, intimidating dean (Helen Mirren, wonderfully severe).
Manages to evoke the crimson-splashed shockers of the 1970s without so much as a single frame of actual carnage.
Funny is funny, and it would be truly dishonest to deny the big laughs-the spikes of gut-busting inspiration-that the film sporadically delivers.
The performances are strong enough ... to almost completely compensate for the tossed-off nature of the movie, which basically amounts to a bunch of close friends getting together to stage a reading.
A pervasive mood of paranoia and unease overwhelms any immediate understanding of what's going on. It's fun to feel lost, at least for a spell.
For all its expensive grandeur, almost too epic even for the vast canvases of IMAX, Pacific Rim is unmistakably a Del Toro creation.
What the film lacks in originality it mostly makes for in personality-a quality fatally lacking from too many contemporary extreme-horror offerings.

For all its chronic familiarity, the movie has its minor pleasures, many of them visual. Though at this point it's basically a given that a new studio-animated movie will look good, Turbo often looks downright exceptional.
Girl Most Likely builds to a climax of such monumental stupidity that it destroys whatever slim pretense of realism the film has heretofore established.
On the page, all of these elements may cohere into something distinctive, perhaps through the help of colorful prose. Onscreen, not so much.
movie_title: The Mortal Instruments: City of Bones (2013)

movie_review_blurb: As a post-financial-crisis movie, Paranoia is muddled at best, wagging its finger at Hemsworth's ambitious bridge-and-tunnel type while fetishizing the life of luxury he cheats his way into.
It's a truly half-assed satire, one whose senseless sensibility seems less informed by the best of English literature than the worst of Saturday Night Live.
Lowery, it can't be denied, has Malick's moves down pat. It's the Malick touch that eludes him.
A juvenile comedy of excess, in which skewering adolescent power fantasies looks an awful lot like indulging in them.
Director David Gordon Green emerges from the billowy cloud of ganja smoke that's swallowed his career, breathing in the refreshing air of the Texas wilderness
It's the cinematic equivalent of those Chinese knockoff luxury sedans.
Characters don't so much have conversations as read Dungeons & Dragons manuals at each other. The whole thing feels like exposition in search of a story.
Appealing though he usually is as an action hero, Damon doesn't have much to do here but scowl and look cool brandishing giant weapons.
There's something adventurous about dicing a deep-space opus into home-video fragments. Call it one small step for found-footage, and leave it at that.
That these moments end up feeling more true than false, as if torn from a diary and not a screenwriting handbook, is thanks principally to the actors bringing them to life.
Liberated from her trademark snark, Plaza tackles the awkwardness of fledgling foreplay with screwball abandon.

It doesn't payoff prior installments or set up future ones, but seems to exist almost out of time, for the simple, quaint purpose of pitting its iconic mutant superhero against samurais, ninjas, and vicious yakuza thugs.

The results are sometimes striking, in pure visual terms, but rarely engaging; even as a brutish saga of underworld retribution, the film fails to get the heart pounding.
As an exercise in classical scare tactics, delivered through an escalating series of primo setpieces, The Conjuring is often supremely effective.
A ponderous vampire romance that surely ranks among the writer-director's most sedate, immobile studies of black life in America.
For 30 screaming-mad minutes, V/H/S/2 achieves a kind of fever pitch of nightmare hysteria.
A portrait of the sheer difficulty in establishing a democratic organization, especially when its prospective practitioners are between 5 and 12 years old.
Chuck doesn't stray far from from the underdog, just-a-lug-from-the-streets redemption arc that Rocky itself helped eternally popularize.

Last Men In Aleppo has the upsetting urgency of breaking news: There are moments that could have come straight from a live stream, given the violence that's still rocking Syria, months after Fayyad's cameras stopped rolling.

Drenched in sweat, looming large but speaking with an impassioned hush, Smith delivers his achronological history lesson like a man possessed, channeling the rage of a nation into a breathless, rat-a-tat flurry ...
What we're watching is a group of ordinary Americans work out, and maybe move past, the dominant public narrative of Ramsey's murder.
How endearing to encounter a sports movie, if it can even be called that, that prints the man instead of his legend.
movie_title: The Happiest Day in the Life of Olli Mäki (Hymyilevä mies) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: What's surprising about A Quiet Passion, given the writer-director's own incurable melancholy, is how lively, how flat-out funny, it frequently is.
This handmade approach is a big part of the film's DIY charm. It's also a perfect match for the story, which seems to have been pulled, too, from the messy locker of teen-boy imagination.
movie_title: My Entire High School Sinking Into the Sea (2017)

movie_review_blurb: This is one of Gere's best performances, somehow both transparent and opaque ...
movie_title: Norman (Norman: The Moderate Rise and Tragic Fall of a New York Fixer) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: This a movie that can think of nothing funnier than arranging three Oscar winners in front of a TV to make catty remarks about The Bachelorette.
There's a strong stylistic integrity to this study of integrity corrupted. What it lacks is the nerve-fraying immediacy of Mungiu's earlier work.
All lavish period detail and stiff upper lips, it's a handsome bore-maybe the most dismayingly ordinary movie Herzog has ever made.
The Blackcoat's Daughter is a clammy hand on the back of the neck, a chill running down the spine, a shot of ice water straight to the veins.
Gage's singular, gendered focus is refreshing; simply offering these young women a platform in which to articulate their immature but still perceptive worldview carries some inherent value.
Life is a B movie on an A budget, an old-fashioned creature feature that delivers its cheap thrills expensively.
In marrying date-movie conventions to reverent tradition, The Wedding Plan brightens both.
You may think of Dilbert one minute, the Nuremberg defense the next. No, really.

Judged just on craftsmanship, Wonderstruck earns its title.
The writer-director has found a way to preserve his razor wit while also deepening his humane appreciation for the screwups he unleashes ...
Le Redoutable is a jokey Wikipedia cartoon of a biopic, skin deep in its character study and aggressively amused by its own barrage of Trivial Pursuit winks.
The Day After gets by on the farcical nature of its entanglements-in moments, it plays like a delightful comedy of misunderstanding.
It's like Cape Fear by way of The Shining, just in the same absurdist register as all of the Greek director's trips to the Twilight Zone.
movie_title: The Killing of a Sacred Deer (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Without a fresh master thesis, all we're basically watching here is the director go back to the well of bourgeois critique, rehashing ideas he's better explored elsewhere.
It unleashes Kurosawa's more playful side-his comic instincts and a largely concealed flair for action-movie pyrotechnics, albeit of the budget variety.
A truthful and sublimely bittersweet slice of life, tracing celebratory highs and lamentable lows on the outer economic edges of the Sunshine State.
It's a gripping portrait of boots-on-the-ground activism, at least so long as it keeps the focus squarely trained on the actual activism.
movie_title: BPM (Beats Per Minute) (120 battements par minute) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It's a spare, brutal, well-crafted prison drama, anchored by an at-turns wildly aggressive and hauntingly vulnerable lead performance by Green Room's Joe Cole.

This is a movie with a lot on its mind, from art to altruism to the so-called bystander effect, and it could function as a Rorschach test for its audience, reflecting viewers' anxieties and insecurities right back at them.
A radical, perplexing departure for the filmmaker, and not necessarily a welcome one.
movie_title: Let the Sun Shine In (Un beau soleil intérieur) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Unfortunately, the movie's often-astonishing imagery ... has been applied to a mainstream thriller that might charitably be called goofy and more accurately described as powerfully stupid.
Finds the South Korean director returning to the genre-jumping mode of his masterpiece, The Host, but not quite nailing the tonal juggling act he achieved with that exhilarating creature feature.
To say that Desplechin loses the thread would only be partially accurate. It's more like he lights the thread on fire like a fuse.
Further proof that of all the genres he dabbles in, samurai cinema is the one that brings out the grandest entertainer in Miike. Here's to 100 more.
movie_title: Blade of the Immortal (Mugen no jûnin) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Zvyagintsev's harsh truths, coupled with his uncharitable characterizations, still strike me as too obvious by half. But there are details here worth savoring ...
You'd think a movie with this much screwing would at least feel less like a statue itself, immobile and damnably honorary.
Shiny but not exactly new, Bill Condon's live-action Beauty And The Beast is a curious nostalgia object, synthetically engineered to reproduce all the same sensations as a 26-year-old movie.

Ultimately more interested in gorilla warfare than the guerilla kind, Skull Island looks from a distance like a Vietnam polemic with a monster painted onto it. But the opposite is truer. It's a King Kong movie -- a state-of-the-art monster mash.
Come for the breathtaking architectural scenery, stay for the likable pair staring up at it.
Has Casey Affleck found a new way to make inexpressiveness expressive, to scrawl emotion across a blank slate?

The filmmaker's gift for procedural and environmental detail still shines brightly through the pulpy crime fiction, this time indebted a little less to Cormac McCarthy's existential brand of the stuff.
If the film is novelistic in its sprawl, maybe sometimes to a fault, it's written in poetry as well as prose.

The film seems chiefly informed by other movies; the generic combat scenes are staged with the same shaky handheld "urgency" as every other Iraq War picture, while the characters have no psychology beyond the usual innocence-lost arc.
Its central mystery keeps you guessing, right up until a final turn that's nearly as clever as it is convoluted.
Dayveon simply cribs from the Southern-fried playbook of its own big-name producer, David Gordon Green.
On a whole, this is an agreeable sophomore effort from the filmmaker-a Sundance movie in one of the better senses.

The Big Sick is an enormous crowdpleaser, funny and touching in about equal measure, built atop an intense experience, and wise about the ways we interact with both our own parents and those of the people we date.
I Don't Feel At Home begins to resemble nothing so much as a Coen brothers imitation with thinner characters.
movie_title: I don't feel at home in this world anymore. (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Truth To Power may be more of an honest-to-God movie than its predecessor, but it's not nearly as purposeful.
movie_title: An Inconvenient Sequel: Truth To Power (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A scraggly and much too familiar British family drama.

Feldman, who played Ginsberg on Mad Men, and Thirlby, who's probably still best known as the best friend in Juno, lend shading to characters whose personal and professional lives seem stuck at the first-draft stage.
Jarmusch, that aging ambassador of cool, sincerely respects both the the ordinariness and the artistry of his blue-collar hero. One does not contradict the other. They are intimately related.

It's superbly unpredictable, moving fluidly into thriller territory and back again.

This stunt-driven nonfiction project rearranges the well-reported dirt on the church, placing it into the context of something considerably less useful: a documentary about how hard it is to make a documentary about Scientology.
A deadly fusion of the mundane and the affected, like some black-box-theater parody of an Ingmar Bergman art drama.
Really, everything in Patti Cake$ is a prelude to uplift; a familiar feel-good trajectory emerges from playing connect the dots with the tropes and recycled plot points.
In more ways than one, Catfight lives down to its title.
It's not déjà vu. You have seen this movie before.

What's special about Logan is that it manages to deliver the visceral goods, all the hardcore Wolverine action its fans could desire, while still functioning as a surprisingly thoughtful, even poignant drama-a terrific movie ...
Without any period-specific music to help establish a sense of time and place-a real cultural backdrop-even the setting remains a little fuzzy.

It just kind of sits there, passively observing its characters, perhaps in hope that the believability of the events will automatically breed drama or a thesis or a philosophy or something. It doesn't.
This is the kind of singularly strange production that you appreciate for its excess and lumpiness, for the way it strays haphazardly out of blockbuster comfort zones.
Land Of Mine is tough and admirably grim, turning a harrowing history lesson into a study in how the battles of wartime don't always cease with the ceasefire.
It's not a terrible setup. But Rings doesn't end up doing much with its fresh ideas.

It's the kind of processed-cheese tearjerker, completely devoid of shame, that can harden even the easiest criers into heckling cynics. You want to take its lunch money or at least introduce it to better music.
Dark Night isn't really a polemic. It's a mysterious elegy for a community on the verge of a nightmarish crucible.
Dickinson is quietly excellent in the lead role, conveying hints of the emotions that Frankie, immersed in his macho go-nowhere social circle, can't bring himself to articulate.
The film picks up when it gets down to shot-by-shot analysis, allowing editors and other interviewees to break down one of the most famous sequences in movie history.

Once again, the Steve James model of long-term filming commitments pays off: By the end of Quest, I felt melancholy about saying goodbye to the Raineys and sad that I wouldn't know where their lives would go from here.
Harrelson, with his goofball stoner energy, can't help but bring a certain gregarious charm to the role, even when, say, casually insulting a date or shouting obscenities at people on the street.
Call Me By Your Name's erotic tension wouldn't crackle so loudly without the chemistry between its leads.

Peele doesn't just subvert a genre often dinged for making people of color expendable cleaver-fodder. He also flips pearl-clutching, white-flight anxiety about predatory black men on its ear, turning a gated community into the real danger zone.
Barry doesn't so much offer glimmers of the man Obama would become as lay experiential groundwork for his later life choices.

Coppola immerses us in a world of verdant outdoor beauty, hushed indoor quiet, and dutiful routine. It's a nice place to visit, but we can see in the yearning glances of the women that living there would be another matter entirely.
The sheer scope of the project demands recognition. It misses the moon by a galaxy, but at least it is has the nerve to take the shot.
What's the point of a less extreme version of a film whose whole raison d'être was extremity?
Plummer ... turns out to be the best thing about All The Money In The World.
movie_title: All the Money in the World (2017)

movie_review_blurb: More than just an advertisement for the process depicted, The Work carries a profound, implicit point about a culture that encourages men to bottle up what they feel, then condemns them after those emotions express themselves in violent, destructive ways.
Heavy with horror though it may be, Foxtrot turns out to be too conceptually and stylistically audacious to be called a slog; it keeps throwing curveballs, some crueler than others.

A duet of affection and irritation, Phantom Thread teeters, too, on the edge of romantic comedy. There's a lot of humor in its passive-aggressive tug-of-war.

To be fair to Denzel, who tends to be reliably commanding even when slumming it in commercial crap, it's hard to imagine anyone doing wonders with this particular title role.
It makes an ageless space god with the nobility of King Arthur and the bodacious abs of a supermodel look like an underdog. Fallibility, not lightning, is his secret weapon.
Leatherface ... falls squarely in the tradition of a series that's failed, movie after movie, to recapture the raw, reptilian power of its first entry.
Once the novelty of the genre swap wears off, you're just watching another inferior variation.
The film's most stylistic gestures all feel like transparent attempts to disguise the blatant, inherent theatricality.
If Blade Runner gave us the world, Blade Runner 2049 has come to fill in the universe.

It's flimsy genre junk of the most generic variety, just with a really groan-worthy Facebook spin.
If it doesn't entirely exploit the potency of its metaphor, there's still a certain grim fun in seeing Taylor give "family feud" an outrageous new meaning.

It tells us more about the filmmakers' cutesy-poo sensibilities than how they feel about the loved one they've lost.
The film's messy mix of flavorful, sometimes over-the-top character comedy and sincere racial politics benefits from the voice of its stars, who also wrote the script ...
The resulting set-pieces are as scary as anything in a fictional horror movie.
It's an awkward concoction, but one too offbeat to entirely dismiss.
All that speculative fun has been shaped into a rather clunky, derivative bit of supernatural claptrap: a haunted house movie curiously low on mystery or honest scares.
Damsel is both on-point and one-note: a curiosity without much going for it beyond its progressive flipping of script.
As a depiction of a certain corner of American life, Leave No Trace is vivid and true.

It's pure emotional terrorism, gripping you with real horror, the unspeakable kind, and then imbuing the supernatural stuff with those feelings. It didn't play me like a fiddle. It slammed on my insides like a grand piano.
A film about memory: the way it distorts and omits, creating an imperfect record, sometimes to shelter us from the harsh reality of our pasts.
A lovely, truthful comedy about the pure nightmare that is junior high.
Did Dano pick up this uncommon fledgling restraint from one of the many first-rate filmmakers for whom he's acted?
A scattershot, intermittently pointed satire whose jokes and insights land with about the same (in)frequency.
Were scientists to engineer an uncut, 100-proof cult sensation, it would probably look, sound, and kick like this.
Lizzie offers speculative explanation, but its theories end up answering a different question: What if Heavenly Creatures was kind of boring?
After a briefly discombobulating fake-out twist, Piercing can't seem to figure out how to advance or complicate its sick-joke premise.
American Animals is ultimately a fairly straightforward heist movie, albeit a stylish and engaging one.
Don't Worry isn't some tearfully inspirational tribute to Callahan's triumph over his disability. It's a tearfully inspirational tribute to his triumph over alcoholism.
movie_title: Don't Worry, He Won't Get Far on Foot (2018)

movie_review_blurb: Plainly, painfully personal.
It's a small, offbeat movie, punctuated by bursts of terrible violence but also infused with a winning strain of deadpan humor that's not too far removed from Jim Jarmusch.
movie_title: Marlina the Murderer in Four Acts (2017)

movie_review_blurb: This is a kitchen-sink drag.
The film may resonate for anyone who's grown up under the unhealthy supervision of a mean bastard. Take that as a sobering recommendation.
For a film with six screenwriters, Homecoming creates a remarkably coherent vision of a smart kid still dumb about the world, battling the learning curves of his double lives.

[A] frequently funny, agreeably bawdy farce, which imagines what a convent of the grubby, violent, disease-infested Middle Ages might look and sound like if it were populated by characters straight out of a modern NBC sitcom.
Everything in Baby Driver, from the rubber-on-road action scenes to the expositional conversations, is its own kind of set piece, engineered to hit pleasure centers with homing-missile accuracy.
By its unforgiving conclusion, Harmonium has plunged headlong into tragedy, but not quite in the way you might imagine.
Pixar's brand can withstand some damage, but there's no denying that a cornball time-burner of a sequel like Cars 3 counts as a big loss.

Though occasionally enlivened by Cruise's willingness to endure a nonstop gauntlet of humiliation, this is a modern blockbuster in many of the worst ways; it's noisy but rarely exciting, heavy on whizzing and whirling special effects but light on wonder.
You'll believe you're watching two people who love each other but no longer know how to live with each other. You may still wish Band Aid better distinguished their relationship.
The best thing about Wonder Woman, the overlong and intermittently enjoyable new DC superhero spectacular, is Wonder Woman herself.

It's all watchable, but in the way of a rainy Saturday afternoon Law & Order marathon, even with Kruger wrestling to invest scenes of her snorting and free-basing her pain away with emotional authenticity.
The Purge sequels do this kind of thing with a lot less fuss.

Slick as the polished marble surfaces of its locations-museums, high-end restaurants, posh living rooms and offices-L'Amant Double steadily disappears down a whirlpool of kinky sex, melodramatic mystery, and thriller bombast.
Ramsay has made a terrific short story, economical as hell but also so moment-for-moment gripping that you want to pore over its every shot, its every dark cranny.
Pattinson finally bursts out of the chrysalis of his pin-up boy celebrity. The metamorphosis from YA heartthrob into electrifying character actor is complete.
Mooney denies this childlike fish-out-of-water any deeper layers of anxiety, dread, or anger. His trauma remains abstract.

King throws herself into the high school melodrama of Wish Upon, but the movie buries her range-from flustered infatuation to horror-flick panic-under a mountain of unbelievable behavior and tin-eared dialogue.

A film that's a lot like the last one, just not quite as funny or endearing.
An ordeal is about all the movie offers.
movie_title: What Will People Say? (Hva vil folk si) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Ayouch pointlessly, gracelessly entwines the fates of five thinly sketched types ... whose aimless arcs don't so much climatically intersect as reach the same Hail Mary non-ending simultaneously.
Its application of [Iannucci's] signature barbed comic voice to such grim history (executions are a constant source of gallows humor) packs its own punch.
The beastliness offsets the beauty nicely, like splotches of grisly red on the film's lustrous, sea foam-green color palette.

I grimly admired the crushing way that it sidesteps romantic baloney at almost every turn, including subverting whatever assumptions we might have about the ultimate role Buscemi's surrogate father figure might play.
Zama, despite its setting, isn't such a radical departure for Martel; it preserves her talent for tracking an individual through chaotic social spheres ...

Trier remains precisely attuned to emotional wavelengths; as a queer campus love story, of sorts, Thelma has the right temperament, thanks in part to the nakedly vulnerable performance the director coaxes from his lead.
Green, Gyllenhaal, and ... Tatiana Maslany hit some grace notes-and plant the germ of some interesting ideas-en route to the expected lifting of spirits.

Lady Bird is something truly special: a coming-of-age comedy so funny, perceptive, and truthful that it makes most other films about adolescence look like little more than lessons in cliché.
