Quote not available.

A slow-burning cinematic riddle that worms its dreamy abstractions through the likes of melodrama, comedy, horror, fable, and documentary, [the film] is a free-spirited, hypnotic masterpiece-and that's not a word to be thrown around lightly.
movie_title: Uncle Boonmee Who Can Recall His Past Lives (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A propulsive ride worth your popcorn dollar, not for its preposterous genre tinkering but for its refreshingly humanist take on a high-concept gimmick.
Nearly every conflict is built on market-tested platitudes of empowerment and registers as insincere.
It's a singularly adventurous film experience that invites intellectual hyperbole, yet its overstretched ambitions also make for Malick's least emotionally satisfying work to date.
A clever crowd-pleaser... In the surrogate Allen role, the typically zonked Owen Wilson smartly underplays with puppy-dog drollness...

The best film screened at Cannes ... Visually breathtaking ... The intimacy and rich, award-worthy performances ultimately sell this meditation on overwhelming angst as a supreme, matured step forward for von Trier.

A choice ride that turns every corner like it's on rails. Refn is a thrilling composer of clean, widescreen geometry and abstract tableaux, turning Driver's bloody, messy descent into hell into a glowingly lit tapestry of memorable, screen-filling faces.

A rich, thorny and haunting portrait of female self-searching through self-negation (or more accurately, why liberation cannot be found in passivity) that comes couched in an abstract, psychosexual nightmare.
A marvelous and moving work of art we need to talk about.
movie_title: We Need to Talk About Kevin (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Like an overlong episode of Curb Your Enthusiasm with none of the wit and twice the irritation.
A hilariously bonkers saga... a story whose twists are unthinkable.

In the late Dennis Hopper's mind a better film than Bertolucci's Luna and his own Easy Rider, the actor-director's brilliant, still shockingly subversive 1980 cherry bomb is as sad and unsettling as dysfunctional-family dramas come.
This wonderfully whimsical examination into the fear of cosmic insignificance is so deeply touching and honest (think Ikiru starring Silver Lake hipsters) you just might need a stiff drink afterward.
[A] Manhattan-set comedy of errors that's seriously more error than comedy.

Irresistibly delightful... visually sly... Even if all its dialogue is written on English intertitles, The Artist sings to life, maintaining a brisk rhythm and too much heart to be dismissed as kitsch.

Writer-director Joe Cornish's charmingly zippy debut wants to be taken seriously while evoking a childlike sense of marvel, or at least early-blockbuster nostalgia. (Is this the inner-city companion to Super 8?)

(Critic's Pick) This patient but wildly expressionistic mosaic uses a canvas so vast that not just the subjects but fighting fish, cockroaches and the mangiest rat yet committed to cinema complete a bizarre ecosystem of co-dependence.

Hustwit gorgeously enhances the talking-head commentaries of architects, policymakers, and other progressive thinkers with spatially clean, static-camera compositions -- this time in God's-eye panoramas of earth's ant farm.
An upbeat but never sugarcoated look at how cultural diversity can provide as many roadblocks as it does opportunities.
Oka!, a loose-limbed tapestry of cultural nuances, atmosphere, and song, is a tuneful tribute to the Bayakan spirit.
By the end of the movie, Winter has become a mascot for human disability, especially for children, and Dolphin Tale has enough depth and sensitivity to tap into emotion without feeling manipulative.
Respectful, loving, but never lionizing, Carl's thorough investigation transcends his personal catharsis to become an enduring treatise on how character flaws affect policy.
movie_title: The Man Nobody Knew: In Search of My Father, CIA Spymaster William Colby (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Granito becomes both a humanitarian legal thriller and a quest to find justice through cinema.
Apes Hollywood rom-com formulas with a personality so affably lobotomized it wouldn't dare frighten delicate tastes.
movie_title: It Takes A Man And A Woman (2013)

movie_review_blurb: True terror needs at least some authenticity. That's perhaps too much to ask of a faked movie about a faked reality show that still can't scare up a fresh idea.
Baroquely sinister and grotesquely funny.
The ensemble's amped-up histrionics rub against each other without ever catching fire.
So tapped into its audience's giddy schadenfreude that beyond a kinkier-than-usual jolt of black humor and some clever red herrings, the formula remains rote...
The film's title needs a question mark, as our drowning heroine must grab her own bootstraps, but for all its sincerity, the film is as average and forgettable as most CBS comedies.

Screenwriters, take note: Unless your story is a whodunit, it's an unforgivable flaw to telegraph early and often that, sometime during the final act, we should anticipate the proverbial rug to be pulled.
Even if The Ledge couldn't be written off as a hollow polemic, there's also the lifeless drama, laughable dialogue, chintzy sets, and poor lighting to grapple with.
Ridiculously implausible yet still predictable.
Even the added visual dimension, thankfully used more for spatial recognition than splashing at us, can't compensate for impersonalized characters stuck under rocks. 127 Hours this ain't.
More heartfelt, humanistic, and entertaining than such a clichéd showbiz cautionary tale has any right to be.
Teases out unanswered existential and behavioral questions about mankind's curious obsession with artificial intelligence and automation.
The persistent references to cinema and film writing are self-awarely mimicking clichés but not subverting them.

Schoenaerts and his lack of bodice-busting tension with Winslet mirrors the film's transparent, often anachronistic inauthenticity: He's a modern Belgian using a regal British accent to play seventeenth-century French.
Let this be a case study for filmmakers everywhere: Scenes centered on search-engine discoveries will never, ever be cinematic.
A basic-cable-caliber drama in which tragic outsiders harbor obscured small-town secrets and the overconfident belief they're characters in a Eugene O'Neill play.
Harps on the retrograde ideas that women should all aspire to be married, and happiness is a permanent state of being that the virtuous can achieve.

Elegantly shot to emphasize the suffocating atmosphere of its believably frightening scenario, the film speaks clearly about generational expectations and the disintegration of the middle class, even when the brothers communicate without using words.

Watching a spy sit on the couch waiting for text messages from higher-ups may not sound as compelling as a le Carré novel, but it's a necessary build to a pulse-pounding third act that reveals how lives are destroyed by half-truths and hearsay.
The best superhero vigilante movie of the year.
The cinematography is far too slick, and Diddy's title song is overplayed, but most of the revelations and one climactic confrontation cut to the bone.
A slyly radical psychosexual oddity busting through genre conventions, beyond its Old West Arizona setting ...
The filmmakers blend tones like a child mixing fountain drinks into one unidentifiable flavor.

So unpretentious that it could be accused of lacking style or vigor, writer-director Marya Cohn's maturely conceived, Kickstarter-budgeted debut swaps genders on the more traditionally male-driven story of a stunted coming-of-age.
It's rare that a drama shows such specificity with respect to the experience of coping with autism, and that sensitivity goes a long way.
Glossily shot yet soullessly schematic ...
As stylish, scorched-earth entertainment, it'll get you in its teeth.

The performances are undeniably authentic, the cinematography could make Terrence Malick stand to give a slow clap, and sometimes a sensitive mood and evocative milieu are enough to sustain when there's barely a plot.
I literally cried tears of joy.
[A] feeble soap opera that's as stilted and unsexy as an adolescent dry hump.
movie_title: An Eye for Beauty (Le règne de la beauté) (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Dizzily entertaining when the knives, bullets, and feet are flying, and sometimes painfully melodramatic during the interim exposition.
The film's alchemic blend of Bressonian rigor, Hitchcockian suspense, and overall proto-Nouvelle Vague cool more than compensates for its straightforward plotting ...
movie_title: Elevator to the Gallows (Ascenseur pour l'échafaud) (1958)

movie_review_blurb: Herzog smartly takes a broad, bird's-eye perspective of our early techno-evolution.
movie_title: Lo and Behold, Reveries of the Connected World (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The footage relies more on idealistic testimonies than a cinematic experience showcasing DBA's vitality; why not let those blistering, immersive concert performances play longer than a chorus?
movie_title: Goodnight Brooklyn: The Story of Death by Audio (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Loopy, irreverent, and more intensely personal than anything its mystic creator has invented before.
Machines proves both uncompromising and unforgettable.
A little power corrupts absolutely in this caustically clever Slovak-language dramedy from the prolific Czech director-writer team of Jan Hrebejk and Petr Jarchovsky
This thanklessly watchable film ... may not warrant Holden Caulfield's trademark judgment of phoniness - but, like any clichéd writing, deserves rejection.

Each neorealist story thread doubles as a case study for how our ever-shrinking world redefines culture and communication, but played as a downbeat comedy of misunderstandings in which Xiaobin mimics Buster Keaton's expressionless disenchantment.
A hokey female-driven drama that liberally fails the Bechdel test.
Offers modest pleasures yet never quite commits to being contemplative poetry or probing journalism.
movie_title: Hong Kong Trilogy: Preschooled Preoccupied Preposterous (Hoeng gong saam bou kuk) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: There's more substance than pastiche in performance artist and documentarian Camille Thoman's ambitious narrative feature debut.
Atom Egoyan's atypically linear revenge fantasy disingenuously evokes the ghastly legacy of Auschwitz as an artsploitation thriller.
An undeniably bland film in style and story, despite a few elaborately staged fight sequences.

Essentially a single, overlong, wearyingly violent chase sequence with shout-outs to honor and maintaining traditions, the story isn't much more than an excuse to keep the artery-spraying war of attrition going.
As the waves of this cinematic dream break, the profundities left behind come not from character arcs, but observed states of being that feel subjectively experienced.
134 minutes of pointless pomposity ...

There are broad, lazy bits about huckster opportunism, an activist beauty who loves the beast philanthropically and romantically, that old punching-bag reality television, and flatly delivered burbling from other screwball rubes.
movie_title: Neander-Jin: The Return of the Neanderthal Man (2013)

movie_review_blurb: In a just-right 39 minutes, Karoff gets Paulette to open up about his strained relationships with friends and family ...
Michael Palmieri and Donal Mosher's tragicomically beautiful art-doc ... sensitively favors unflinching testimonials and visually impressionistic observations over journalistic activism.

As scuzzy, schizoid and defiantly lo-fi as ever, punk-rock auteur Jon Moritsugu proves with his Kickstarter-funded first feature in over a decade that there's still a cinematic underground in the post-Internet world.

If the banality of life within the Bordeaux gentry is the point, then the ensuing oppressiveness is immaculately depicted through precise performances and camerawork-just don't call it emotionally engaging drama.
Doesn't try to be anything more than a soft-serve pull of treacly pandering.

Reiterates a famous Talking Heads question of midlife existentialism ("You may ask yourself, well, how did I get here?") but doesn't offer enough in the way of subtext or mise-en-scène to fashion an answer.
Kazan holds together a decent coming-of-age script that's emotionally sincere if tonally unfocused.
Deadened by milquetoast characters, uninspired landscape photography, and no perceptible stakes.

Seven decades later, the creative well has somehow not yet run dry on the ripple effects of Nazi Germany's offenses, though writer-director Georg Maas's slick and sulky second feature is not another dime-a-dozen Holocaust tragedy.
There's very little to distinguish this from every other characterless rom-com with a demographically marketable hook.
More social-studies lesson than cinema ...
movie_title: From Both Sides Of The Aegean: Expulsion And Exchange Of Populations, Tukey-greece 1922-1924 (2014)

movie_review_blurb: This occasionally stirring doc portrait of the late Latino labor organizer and civil rights icon frames his legacy around a single act of protest.
The magnetism between these stiff nonstarters wouldn't stick to a fridge, especially when the war-ex-machina forces them apart for years but the only credible passing of time is our own.

Perhaps if Moll offered less of the static sit-down interviews and more fly-on-the-grain vérité, viewers might feel some new, intimate connection between the farmers and the nourishment that unites us.
Both strands of the narrative intersect with one last reveal of unresolved melodrama that feels coldly calculated in its cause and effect.
Even at its most compulsively watchable ... the film is as shallow as its characters' oversexed conversations.
A precisely paced, nightmarish thriller.
Glossy, lifelessly paced ...

Freeland's conventional yet credible portrait of identity crises on the reservation covers familiar ground (alcoholism, poverty) while warmly exploring contemporary issues rarely filmed within the diverse community.
[Garrett's] handsome and fiddles something fierce, but his acting aptitude is more "Chopsticks" than Caprice no. 24 in A minor.

This blatantly big-hearted product isn't half as vibrant as the original 2005 Wired article on which it's based, and myopically neglects to address Arizona's troubling anti-immigration legislation through even a splash of hindsight.
Since the conversation is unfocused and there's no real thesis, we get a girl and a gun but not really a movie.

All the secrets, lies, and consequences feel as authentic as the Appalachian milieu, but the film lacks the memorable idiosyncrasy of a River's Edge, or more fittingly, the myth-making lyricism of Matewan.
Much like his fly-boyflyboy underdog in the opening sequence, Wilson simply can't stick the landing.
The film uses its phantasmagoric conceit, a sickly-hued poetry, and eerie sound design to build metaphors for closeted homoeroticism and melancholic unfulfillment.
Attempts to offer the white-knuckle gratifications of a studio procedural with a conspicuous lack of production values, screen talent, plausibility, originality, or a lick of aesthetic flair.
Just because you're paranoid doesn't mean your speculations are sound, your writing and filmmaking skills are passable, or that you're preaching to anyone but the fearfully converted.
Come for the cult of personality, stay for the nostalgia of a dirtier, dodgier, far cooler scene.
Finnish visual artist Eija-Liisa Ahtila's experimental narrative truly pushes forward the possibilities of split-screen cinema.
Canadian comedy hits rock bottom in this abhorrent meta-infomercial for a Funny or Die-like network boasting uncensored online content ...
The film is entertaining but hardly penetrating.

A wonderfully faithful throwback to the '60s animated features (and the original Ernest H. Shepard book illustrations that inspired the studio's watercolored, 2-D look) with a modest veneer of postmodern cleverness.
There's something crassly disingenuous about the movie's blatant demographic pandering (hooray for immigration-panic jokes!) and half-a--ed condemnation of gluttony.
It's an exhilarating document.
How much can we possibly glean from a guy whose idealism can be measured with a calendar?
At best, it's a perfunctory narrative, complete with title cards that clunkily hit the same bullet points that might appear on one of those rally fliers.
Any amateur magician can successfully yank the tablecloth away, but it's only impressive if there's something of value on the table.
This is mighty perplexing nerd kibble, its highfalutin' philosophical and psychological banter way too outlandish to seriously engage. Yet as a visceral experience, it's entrancing.
movie_title: Evangerion shin gekijôban: Jo (Evangelion: 1.0 You Are (Not) Alone) (Neon Gensis: Evangelion 1.01 You Are (Not) Alone) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The Burning Plain marks Arriaga's behind-the-camera debut, and his obviousness is staggering.
It's yet another '80s slasher remake, so you know the drill...er, the tire iron pimped out with blades.
It's a slickly enjoyable production (if unfocused and bloated), and his bullet-point tips are persuasive; but dude, there are better ways to humanize these issues than crying on camera.
It's overly faithful to the original and to Van Gogh's preferred three-camera setup.

Steadily maintaining momentum and a meditative mood without narration or editorialization is itself a feat, but more vitally, Paradise appreciates and shares the curious mysteries in the seemingly banal.
DiPietro's screenplay is emotionally myopic. His sharpest written exchanges -- and there aren't many -- get buried under his inexplicable need to embrace the non-linear conceit.
There may as well be a road sign announcing Diane's transformation from reckless loner to diligent mother, but it's a smooth ride thanks to Monaghan, and an impressive ensemble.
[Waiting for Forever is] strangely unaware of its overt creepiness.
The vampire trend continues, but the only authentic bloodsuckers in Cirque du Freak are its producers and studio execs.
movie_title: Cirque du Freak: The Vampire's Assistant (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Duffy is still chasing his perfect slide-and-shoot, except now with more self-satisfied posturing, awkward pop-culture referencing, casual homophobia and racism, and the most vulgar co-opting of religious iconography this side of Dan Brown.
movie_title: The Boondock Saints II: All Saints Day (2009)

movie_review_blurb: This shapeless series of unfunny vignettes (interspersed with pointless street interviews) deserves to be slapped hard.
We've seen enough movies to know Joshua will stop being a jerk after he learns the true meaning of Christmas, but it's almost impossible to disparage such genuine warmth.
... effortlessly and damningly dissect[s] the ugliness of beauty culture.
movie_title: Une femme mariée: Suite de fragments d'un film tourné en 1964 (A Married Woman) (1964)

movie_review_blurb: It's a melodramatic premise on paper that, in the wrong hands, might have succumbed to the sensationalism of its mildly incestuous undertones.
From rockabilly freakouts to an acoustic lullaby, the soundtrack here is diverse, catchy and easily the film's most exuberantly charming quality.
A simplistic, straightforward tale that's beautifully staged with the same wave of the magical-realism wand that powers Jeunet & Caro's Delicatessen.
Updates the spirit of blaxploitation without feeling pressed to worship or satirize it.
If you can settle into [Baard Owe's] playful deadpan rhythms, a bittersweetly funny, existential mystery -- or call it a modest adventure, if that's not too oxymoronic -- awaits.
This Lifetime-ready comedy is hardly provocative -- let alone perceptive, funny, or fresh.
Naturalistic, semi-improvised series of awkward comic vignettes ... nails the liberating/frightening social moments of post-pubescence in all their riches of embarrassments.
What's most beautiful of all is that this document ensures that these people will indeed live on forever. Take that, Nazis!
It's heartbreaking, of course, but also crassly manipulative and blandly shot, too.

All the slapdash animation, stock footage, fake Robert narration, and cred-boosting testimonials here (Yoko Ono, Donovan, Genesis P. Orridge) offer less insight than father Palmer's own book-turned-doc Deep Blues.
Potent and wisely straightforward.
Turning Green is, if nothing else, the world's loneliest teen sex comedy.
The film never finds drama, focus or any greater purpose other than some dubious horn-blowing about the SEIU being singularly responsible for electing President Obama.
Spread eventually reveals a gloomy raincloud of a moral meditation about unhealthy lifestyles and self-delusion.
Somewhere on the streets of Chinatown, this is a black-market DVD optimistically renamed Klerks, though even Kevin Smith's debut didn't seem this amateurish.
Proves how easy it is to shamelessly bilk audiences of their empathy with an "inspired by true events" credit.

What held in the animator's previous films as eccentrically multifaceted dream logic comes off for once as a series of non sequiturs -- but really, why complain while sucking on an Everlasting Gobstopper of eye candy?
The film is confidently polished and thankfully more sweet-tempered than preachy, given that every narrative thread has an underlying theme of social injustice.
As we fade out with Easy and sons bonding over steak and beers, our cockles are warmed -- the movie forgotten.
Every line of dialogue sounds contrived, right up to the phony-baloney twist ending.
With 19 producers, one wonders how many rich Floridians invested in what might be the year's most unambitious comedy.
The Pope's Toilet entertains, even while it illustrates how the impoverished can adjust their religious ideals out of desperation.
movie_title: El Baño del Papa (The Pope's Toilet) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Where most documentarians would rest on the laurels of a great subject and riveting present-tense drama, director Jeremiah Zagar has observed too much of his father's creative logic to cheat us with artless hagiography.
Evolution is far more entertaining than it deserves to be, unless you're a 10-year-old boy, in which case it's only the greatest movie ever made.
From the imperialist villains and their humanitarian abuses to the laborers dying on their feet, what's so clever about tricking out this worn-out tale of woe into a genre flick?
I dearly hope John Malkovich got paid handsomely for his two days of embarrassment on-set.
All the jams are fabulously stirring but not sappy, especially when Fleck duels with a Gambian man on a three-string akonting (forefather to the banjo), but there's nothing more to the film.
Talk about false advertising: There is no bebop or a single blue note in first-time director Lindsey Christian's crushingly slipshod D.C. drama.
Using cinema as self-therapy might be a selfish way to treat audiences, but Harden and Scheel's chemistry makes the mother-daughter dynamic universal.

As his staff prepares for his son's arrival and the piano tuner fills the hacienda with splintered notes, the limited stimulus sparks Antonio's memories, his final hours playing out like delicate, melancholic poetry.
A slickly entertaining and thorough enough curiosity about the form, function, context, inspiration, and evolution of industrial design.

Francis Ford Coppola returns to form with his richest, most enrapturing film since Apocalypse Now. The black-and-white cinematography alone is as intoxicating as a bottle of the director's finest red.
Hilariously perceptive.

Thomas Turgoose reunites with writer-director Shane Meadows in this shaggy, endlessly charming dramedy set in working-class London, wistfully shot in black-and-white... Witty and warmhearted, it's a feel-good movie that never seems forced.
A starkly lyrical portrait of angry, disaffected teens in the racially tense wake of the actual 1996 St. Petersburg, Florida, riots.
[A] humdrum but marketable comedy, starring a handful of humdrum but marketable faces from the small screen.
Unexciting, incoherent, lamely acted, and carelessly written.

Coming down from the Saturday sugar rush of his 2006 comedy Duck Season, Mexican auteur Fernando Eimbcke's lovely, Yucatán-set dramedy drifts by on a similar deadpan wave of static vignettes and lingering pauses that must be 10 months pregnant.
Once the film devolves into a drag-down fight for custody with Julia's mother, only Gusman's nuance saves us from a script that seems geared more toward screeching overacting.
How is it that a film about the love of art can make art seem so detestable?
A cute and mildly clever fantasy.
movie_title: Shorts: The Adventures of the Wishing Rock (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The End of the Line is a free-form splash of jaw-dropping graphs, impressively accredited talking heads, and sumptuously shot portraits of natural beauty and decay, overdramatically scored to symphonic and other intense musical attacks.
Former journalist Megumi Sasaki's warmhearted celebration of these adorable do-gooders cements their significance to the art world and introduces them to the rest of us.
Yes, it's rated PG-13, except it's also inappropriate for anyone over 13.
Michigan-based filmmaker Diane Cheklich's insipid, cheapjack dramedy -- about a flagging company's decision to outsource -- isn't potent enough to even be called a lukewarm-button movie.
It's a pleasant, largely anecdotal portrait.
movie_title: Milton Glaser: To Inform and Delight (2009)

movie_review_blurb: You have to wonder about a debut this self-involved: What's left for the second film?

Sleeping Dogs Lie -- a/k/a "the dog blowjob rom-com" -- planted the seed (OK, wrong choice of words) that Goldthwait wrings tender humanity from disturbing premises, but his scandalously entertaining new satire proves a darker, funnier success.
Serviceably enjoyable, like cold pizza but little more.
With stronger actors and real writers, this might've been a vintage comedy you could sink your...nope, not going there.
Food Beware doesn't even work as cinematic spinach since the nutritional value of its case is as light as a rice cake.
movie_title: Nos enfants nous accuseront (Food Beware: The French Organic Revolution) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Inevitably, the film devolves into weepy catharsis, but with slick cinematography and colorfully cruel dialogue for Scott to chew up and spit at every member of this fine ensemble.
Sol Tryon's dark, irrepressibly hilarious fable offers highbrow absurdism and low-budget filmmaking at their most clever and outlandish.
Seamlessly strung together with a funny-sad tenderness and a gliding casualness that's more purposeful and believable than the unrefined improvisations of most DIY cinema.
Uncompromising and wickedly entertaining ... Casey Affleck leads a rich ensemble cast.

The most original, challenging, and perverse film of the year so far, Giorgos Lanthimos's artfully rigorous treatise on human conditioning can be viewed as absurdist horror or the cruelest of comedies.

Bold, thrilling, and undeniably sensuous melodrama uncannily invokes the pleasures of smell, taste, and touch ... Everything dances here: the camera, the colors, Tilda's eyes, even pollinating bees during a sumptuously shot sex scene.
Mesmerizing ... A trippy nightmare of savage poetry burning slow across bleak and otherworldly landscapes.
Innovative and timelessly hilarious.

Instead of the angry, shrewdly prescient critique of Greed 2.0 we need, we're unfortunately given the product we deserve: an innocuous, overcooked studio entertainment with a hypocritically bloated budget and sense of itself.
Woody Allen doesn't mask his mean-spirited misanthropy in this barely comedic, mostly melodramatic skeleton of a saga ... Superficial and forgettable.
movie_title: You Will Meet a Tall Dark Stranger (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A brisk, perfectly watchable globetrotter that suffers most from Wikipedia Syndrome. That is, events unfold as didactically talky rather than dramatically engaging so that uninformed viewers can catch up on recent history.

Morel's underrated eye and knack for making kinetic movement rhythmic and easy to follow elevates Besson's run-of-the-mill, mismatched-buddy thriller into a propulsive, enjoyably Eurotrashy entertainment.
Methinks we're meant to actually feel sorry for this overprivileged twerp in neon sunglasses.
The love triangle is as tediously underwhelming as the slo-mo action, but the actors, costumes and lush mountainsides are easy on the eye.
This handsomely shot melodrama has a twist too peculiar to dismiss as some two-bit Nicholas Sparks weepie.
It's a project better admired than enjoyed.
Two hours of knife-wielding and shrieking later, nothing significant or profound is gleaned...
Inspiring if straightforward...
Lee's film deals in fusty anti-globalization sentiments and mostly meanders -- aimlessly, impassively, and away from the rich Taiwanese canon.
It's an unusual taste of mainstream Indian cinema, unexpectedly irreverent with an earthier, folkier soundtrack than the typical Bollywood electro-bounce.
Co-collaborators Peter Brosens and Jessica Woodworth still cheapen their ethnological lyricism by over-stylizing the venture as if it were a Benetton ad by Alejandro Jodorowsky-lite.
Though the leads make for a believable family unit, the performances in writer-director Rehana Mirza's thin-skinned, no-frills drama unevenly range from functional to histrionic.
Richman does a bang-up job with rare archival footage and new vérité interviews, even allowing for Gruber's acquaintances and their descendants to grill the still-sharp nonagenarian.

The choreography is sloppy and lifeless; the outmoded blend of vintage rock, country and Broadway styles doesn't click; and the characters are such caricatures that it's no wonder the entire cast is overacting.
It's a mighty awkward adaptation for such an uncomplicated project...
Make no mistake about his ability to make social studies entertaining: A montage about Tibet's many supporters is set to the Beastie Boys playing "Sabotage" live.
Perfunctorily shot and edited, the project hinges only on Rutledge-Taylor's findings, which begin to raise eyebrows once pragmatic activism is thrown out the window in favor of the blame game.
A fruitless portrait of commonplace backstage reveals and indulgent mugging.
Eventually buckles under the weight of affable but unfunny camp.
A partly biographical, drolly fabricated comedy.
It's a film about the frustrations and fears of every parent...
The mismatched buddy shtick with a tender resolution is on autopilot.
This hoary midlife-crisis tale is watchable solely for its reliable cast.

The subgenre's clichéd two-way street of corruption and redemption predictably sees our antihero finding liberation in a childhood sweetheart while facing down the crooked lawman who led him to a life of transgression.
A romcom is a romcom, however, and at least this one's more charming than most of Jennifer Aniston's career.
All the heartfelt references to the 228 Massacre and the White Terror don't make this any more thrilling than a Wikipedia entry.

Spreading social awareness is a valuable pursuit, naturally, but when filmmakers take it upon themselves to don the cape of an activist hero while constantly reminding audiences of their nobility, the message feels cheap.
Inspired by Wang's photo book about older Gothamites whose occupations were threatened by modernity, screenwriter Adam Forgash has fittingly written a scenario as hoary as his characters
Green also can't maintain the suspension of disbelief necessary as we watch three charmlessly written characters bicker and attempt inane ideas.
One-named Cuban-born director Agustin's unrewarding middlebrow drama flaunts its street cred dubiously.
CGI fairy dust, dippy tooth puns and a semi-amusing Billy Crystal cameo can't disguise the fact that this sugary distraction is as hollow as a cavity.

An unconvincingly broad culture-clash comedy whose Latino and African-American ensemble might've made for a progressive film if director and co-writer Rick Famuyiwa hadn't pandered to the lowest common denominator.
If you're not already a member of the "Johnny's Angels" fan club, you might wonder why other equally outrageous athletes weren't bestowed with their own cinematic tributes.
Charming and unexpectedly perceptive.
We get charmless hack work from two sitcom writers, a phoned-in ensemble, and for Allen a vanity role that could certainly be called criminal.
Underreported and over-emotional, Geralyn Pezanoski's 81-minute doc exposé about dogs displaced during Hurricane Katrina moves slower than a basset hound to get to these and other thorny questions.

While the premise might seem like a superficial YouTube stunt, the storytelling is crafty, compelling (falling from a cliff while being chased by a helicopter?!?) and heartfelt enough to explode all sense of cheeky irony.
movie_title: Flooding With Love for the Kid (2010)

movie_review_blurb: South Korean first-timer Na Hong-jin offers nasty thrills, manic foot chases and some genuinely subversive riffs on the police procedural.
The film builds on a fascinating cautionary tale, but doesn't develop its characters past whatever movie-of-the-week crisis each suffers from.

Writer-director Gabriel Medina's chokingly offbeat debut is as aimless and confused as its prototypical slacker-comedy hero, who seems to have wandered into a glum dramedy with a hazy noirish aesthetic.
A potent reminder of how thankless a soldier's job is.
All three leads are solidly convincing in their candor. And Oscar-winning cinematographer Chris Menges (The Mission) shoots the hell out of the swampy South to make for a nontoxic diversion.
If you want an eye-popping cosmic epic, rent Star Trek. If you want interactivity, take the kids to the planetarium.
Treats its subject as a musty artifact under glass by glossing over both its early rough-and-tumble roots and today's neoburlesque resurgence.
So much information, context and personality is squeezed into such a succinct package that, primer or not, you're left with a strongly realized sense of who Halprin is and what she's accomplished.
Director Duncan Ward tries way too hard to nail a way too easy target in his sub-Altman ensemble spoof of the overpriced, overhyped, overly pretentious modern-art scene.
Ramchand Pakistani sadly negates its intentions with frequent TV producer Jabbar's soapy storytelling and too-clean production values.
Watanabe's performance sucks any remaining sweetness right out of this fish-out-of-water comedy; you're ready to call the police once he starts stalking his hot cousin.
A genuinely hip, thought-provoking work of art disguised as a doomed documentary resurrected.
Drop the impotent Michael Moore-esque exposé on the company who manufactured the drug, and this moving doc would, in fact, be perfect.

Barely dramatizing off-the-field struggles like visa problems and the boys' first taste of good ol' American racism, the film does a disservice to the community it depicts by rendering an inspiring cultural story entirely uninspired.
Fresh is a palatable lecture, but we've milked that cow one too many times already.

The rowdy New York midnight premiere of writer-director James Nguyen's self-proclaimed "romantic thriller" Birdemic: Shock and Terror proves that there's room-alongside Ed Wood's entire oeuvre--for one more in the pantheon of beloved trash-terpieces.
What stings throughout this stutter-stop relationship are the spot-on modern details, but the overall hipness is a little too forced -- it's damn funny when it could've been poignant.

Saitzyk's sappy pontifications on loss, redemption, and zealotry don't register as headily as they're meant to, and the spirituality invoked feels about as sincere as the Christian who only attends Christmas mass.
Mark Young's bargain-basement thriller is as witless as the captor's motive; to paraphrase another well-dressed Madsen psycho, this little doggie barks, but it has no bite.
Felix Van Groeningen's highly entertaining tale is full of hilarity, horror and heartbreak (sometimes within the same scene).
Turns out you can make a robo-comedy today, if you know what you're doing.
Suffers from a dreary type of adolescence, missing the spirit of adventure or joy of a good children's film and lacking the comic sophistication necessary to make it interesting for grown ups.
more life than 10 summer blockbusters combined
It almost goes without saying that the animation is jaw dropping.
Sure, it's weepy and sentimental and fails to take full advantage of an emotionally fertile premise. But as a story of loss, self-discovery and rebirth it succeeds as much as it fails.
Frida may not be as audacious as Julie Taymor's directorial debut Titus, but the film displays some real visual flair.
Such a bad, self-satisfied film that you can't help but marvel, and laugh, at it.
It's powered by an increasingly hard to believe series of coincidences, so flagrantly employed that you might even start to believe that A Guy Thing is a clever parody of mindless romantic comedies.
A spirited, good-natured coming of age comedy that encompasses the immigrant experience, gender identity and family expectations with an engaging, natural ease.
Joseph H. Lewis transforms this ostensible B-movie distraction into a notable entry in the film noir pantheon
When it works, you don't care about all the times it doesn't.
movie_title: Once upon a Time in Mexico (2003)

movie_review_blurb: The Last Samurai might have been designed to give Cruise a chance to shine, but to the detriment of the overall film.
profound
movie_title: The Good, the Bad and the Ugly (1966)

movie_review_blurb: Too bad it's not much fun to watch
the window dressing is not enough to buoy the principle acting
movie_title: The Name of the Rose (Der Name der Rose) (1986)

movie_review_blurb: given the sustained noise generated by The Brown Bunny, such a quiet achievement amounts to a resounding success
an irreverent overview of the current geopolitical mess
Technically, Basic seems thrown together at the last minute.

It's rare that a previously established side character, no matter how well loved, can deliver the goods in his own show. Which is probably why nobody tries it with movies. Well, nobody but the makers of Get Him to the Greek.
Sit back, put on your glasses, and enjoy: It's summer, and Pixar has made you a treat.
Iron Man is better when Robert Downey Jr. is alone on the screen than when he's sharing it. It's when those inconvenient other people show up that the movie loses its way.

In trying to decipher how Michael Moore has achieved his widespread popularity in the face of a somewhat cavalier attitude toward factual precision, there's no underestimating his savvy choice of targets.
The Hurt Locker is horrifying. It's hopeless. I want to go see it again.
[Apatow] makes responsibility and commitment funny; no mean feat.

The Girlfriend Experienceis a damning portrait of overindulgence, but it also manages to inspire sympathy for Sasha Grey: not by punishing her, but by gently, persistently reminding her that she became a commodity to achieve a lifestyle.
We are left with the unsettling knowledge that, in the universe crafted by Guillermo del Toro as well as in our own, we are always surrounded by monsters.

A swiftly paced documentary about America's systemic war on women's rights ...

The dopey symbolism of Magda staring down a menacing crab on the beach (get it?) may be the film's biggest takeaway - even a grande dame of the screen can be taken down by stale poetry.

It's all too easy to put a twentysomething protagonist through the motions of a quarter-life crisis and insist you've had an idea, which is what writer-director Bryan Reisberg does with Big Significant Things.
Deranged, often very funny ...
A puzzling film that despite being saturated with feeling leaves only a vague impression.
There's simply too much going on to establish characters. More upsettingly - being that this is a sci-fi film - it's impossible to tell what the cool parts are supposed to be.
Pulled in too many directions, the film's subtle mood-building starts to feel intentionally oblique, the force of its characters and symbols lessened by a frustrating circuitousness.
This would be great ammo for any parents out there who suspect their bartender-DJ son is going down the wrong path; the average viewer will find little justification to continue watching.
Keith Miller's modest drama Five Star is the kind of depiction the city sorely needs.
Like the ravings of a keyed-up screenwriter, there's conviction, if not logic, in its madness, and that makes it fun and fascinating.

Though Topher forges ahead bravely, it's all too clear that he's headed toward an underwhelming conclusion.
The film trudges along in Collette's wake, fumbling for something to focus on apart from the bleeding wound just offscreen.

Ryder's is an earnest, well-meaning performance -- and she also coproduced the movie -- but the book's interesting tension and dark humor are pretty much absent.

No matter your opinion on the Israel-Palestine situation, The Gatekeepers is necessary viewing. It's very impressive that a documentary about Israel's intelligence-gathering organization comes off as neither pro-Israel nor anti-Israel.
The movie may not always be a knee-slapper, but it's smart, creative, and oddly sweet. At the very least, you'll probably never think of brunch the same way again.
Ultimately this movie is better forgotten.

movie_review_blurb: It's got the kind of writing you'd expect to find in a Hitchcock movie, with performances that measure up on every level.

Pontypool has an awful lot going for it. It's technically well made, well acted, creepy, funny, and weird. It's the kind of movie that, if it's seen in the right place and right time, can really have an effect on you.

The Tribe is a film that opens itself to endless conversations, whether they're about the nature of its storytelling or the story it chooses to tell.
Ant-Man stands on its own as an entertaining, smartly funny film, while also fitting neatly into the Marvel cinematic universe.
The Look of Silence is required viewing, equal parts frightening and beautiful, much like the landscape it portrays.
Inconsistent, but really funny. Judged on (Schumer's) own merits and what she's explicitly said she's trying to do, which is to be funny, Trainwreck passes.

Director Sean Baker's wickedly funny and stylish film Tangerine dives deep into the transgender community in Los Angeles in a way that explores the strengths, vulnerabilities, and deep needs of its characters.

Little Men is a poignant reminder that the changes in the places we live often come at a cost to someone else.

A fascinating mix of 70s style, drug-culture weirdness and old-fashioned country charm.
movie_title: A Poem Is A Naked Person (2015)

movie_review_blurb: It's verité filmmaking in the most literal sense of the word.

A gorgeous, moody exercise that is equal parts character study and adventure.

...a taut, intelligent, and visually spellbinding portrait of repression, victimization, and guilt.
...an incisive, acerbic, and droll exploration of voyeurism, exploitation, and repression.
... a harsh, bleak, and profoundly tragic portrait of the dissolution of the national soul.
A structurally challenging, yet emotionally honest, understatedly humorous, and visually compelling choreography of motion, rhythm, and passion.
...a transcendence beyond spiritual captivity towards a lonely, indefinite journey, guided solely by humanity and personal conscience.
A haunting image of lost and aimless spirits... drifting round and round in circles through the empty, soulless rooms of their stifling and claustrophobic corporeality.

movie_review_blurb: Illustrates the instinctuality, mysticism, and idiosyncrasies embedded in the native culture, celebrating the resilient soul of a marginalized national identity.
A barren reflection of the villagers' own existential limbo - a bleak, stagnant, and inert wasteland festering in a hopeless, meaningless, and soulless world.
...a cruel testament to the blind, hypocritical legacy of traditional honor, virtue, and duty.
movie_title: The Life of Oharu (Saikaku ichidai onna) (1952)

movie_review_blurb: An Actor's Revenge is a stylistically bold and irreverent satire that seeks to reconcile the familiar, traditional elements of native culture with the modern vitality of Western influence in contemporary Japan.
A haunting portrait of a national soul struggling against the rootlessness, estrangement, and transience cultivated by its turbulent and irreconcilable past.
A highly accomplished and sensitively realized film.
A sublime and haunting examination of conformity, inhumanity, and abuse of power.
An understated observation of the inevitable passage of time, and the irrepressible longing of the soul to capture an elusive moment of nature's fleeting beauty.
movie_title: El Sol del membrillo (Dream of Light) (Quince Tree of the Sun) (2000)

movie_review_blurb: Tarkovsky uses sharp, contrasting scenes of light and darkness to visually delineate between the idealization of a normal life and its seeming elusiveness in the hopelessness of war.
An intoxicating elegy of motion and stasis, modernization and tradition, hope and nihilism.
Intelligently constructed, compelling, provocative, and relevant observation on social inequity, the untenability of cultural assimilation, and the failure of communication.
movie_title: Code Unknown (Code inconnu: Récit incomplet de divers voyages) (2000)

movie_review_blurb: ...transcends the bounds of geographical, cultural, and personal isolation to map the elusive metaphysical plane of human interconnectedness.
movie_title: Ni na bian ji dian (What Time Is It Over There?) (2001)

movie_review_blurb: Wajda chronicles the social reality of revisionist history, and the tragic irony that results from constantly shifting government policies.
Tarkovsky's personal struggle between love of country and creative freedom culminated during the filming of Nostalghia.
...a hypnotic reflection of the passage of real-time, and we are reminded that we have witnessed one mere episode, one fleeting glimpse, of a wondrous phenomenon called life.
movie_title: Under the Olive Trees (Zire darakhatan zeyton) (Through the Olive Trees) (1994)

movie_review_blurb: Denis reveals the underlying influence of masculine competition and aggression in the everyday conduct of business and human transactions.
Wong Kar-wai creates a spare and elegant film on chance, fate, and unrequited longing .
movie_title: Days of Being Wild (A Fei zheng chuan) (1990)

movie_review_blurb: A profound observation on the trials and tribulations of everyday life, reflected in complex ways -- direct and abstruse -- but all fundamentally, and infallibly, human.
Highly cerebral, beautifully realized, and symbolically obscure, Nostalghia is a cinematic abstract of spiritual hunger.
...exquisitely shot, sublimely haunting, and emotionally complex film on the nature of human relationships.
...a validation of courage and resilience in facing the unknown - a quiet triumph of the human spirit.
To experience a Yasujiro Ozu film is to immerse in the reserved, quiet grace of a disappearing traditional culture.
A cinematically groundbreaking, cryptic, and endlessly fascinating labyrinthine puzzle on memory and altered perception.
movie_title: Muriel ou Le Temps d'un Retour (The Time of Return) (1963)

movie_review_blurb: A beautiful, understated celebration of the wonder of life and the interminable courage of the human soul.
La Strada is Federico Fellini's moving masterpiece that explores the soul's eternal conflict between the heart and mind.
A testament to humanity's tenacity and perseverance, to the inexorable power of compassion and dignity. In essence, a chronicle of the soul.
Arguably Ingmar Bergman's most challenging and experimental film.
An engaging, precisely crafted story of selfless bravery, perseverance, and fraternity.
A highly stylized and extraordinarily unformulaic adaptation of a simple premise.
movie_title: My Life to Live (It's My Life) (Vivre sa vie: Film en douze tableaux) (1962)

movie_review_blurb: A parable of answered prayers: the idea that the distraction of wealth and fame cannot fill the void of loneliness, nor substitute for a soul's unrequited passion.
A touching, humorous, and poignant film about hope and survival.
movie_title: Nights of Cabiria (Le Notti di Cabiria) (1957)

movie_review_blurb: Few films have indelibly defined society as caustically and honestly as Federico Fellini's La Dolce Vita.
A fascinating metaphysical excursion into the enigmatic and wondrous terrain of human emotion: attraction and connection, love and jealousy, the spiritual and the corporal.
A poignant and heartbreaking portrait of an aging man's redemption from a life of crime and deception.
A poignant, lyrical, and allegorical fable on the human struggle for identity and connection.
movie_title: Landscapes in the Mist (Topio stin omichli) (1988)

movie_review_blurb: Inevitably, Guido is as much a reflection of Fellini as he is of ourselves: striving for greatness, only to achieve the ordinary and familiar... with episodes of momentary abstraction in between.
La Grande Illusion is a sublimely poignant and lucidly insightful commentary on the social legacy of the Great War in Europe.
An insightful, universal window into the everyday complexities of contemporary existence
...unsentimental, yet profoundly moving tale of moral idealism, public service, and personal conscience.
The film provides an intelligent and incisive discourse on the need for moral and ethical responsibility, vigilance, awareness, and informed activism.
"A potent denunciation of abuse of power, state-sanctioned discrimination, and unchallenged fear mongering."
...a richly textured, incisive, and provocative examination of outmoded faith, breakdown of family, and spiritual desolation.
movie_title: L' Ora di Religione (Il Sorriso di Mia Madre) (The Religion Hour) (My Mother's Smile) (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Rather than a nostalgic swan song, Bergman has created another provocative chapter in his enduring expositions into the most fundamental human need for connection.
Quote not available.
A sincere, well-intentioned, and technically proficient, but uncharacteristically trite and formulaic portrait of a drug-addicted, washed up celebrity and recent widow.
Quote not available.
movie_title: The Best of Youth (La meglio gioventù) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: A provocative and haunting portrait of disconnection, repression, emotional violence, and intimacy.
movie_title: Aus dem Leben der Marionetten (From the Life of the Marionettes) (1980)

movie_review_blurb: Distilling the essence of the innate intimacy in their unspoken ritual, Wong retains the imbued sensuality of In the Mood for Love and 2046 to create an equally understated and voluptuous tale of transfigured desire.
Quote not available.

Three Times presents a series of vignettes, each chronicling a series of understated encounters between two lovers played by same actors Chang Chen and Shu Qi, as their destinies weave through complex socio-political terrain.
movie_title: Three Times (Zui hao de shi guang) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Life elevated, or reduced, to the hyperbolic artifice of hackneyed drama, to clichéd cinematic constructions.
Ferrara creates a polarizing and blunt, yet astute and unexpectedly compassionate allegory for the inextinguishable creative spirit in all its chaos, volatility, isolation, hope, and exhilaration.
A City of Sadness compassionately articulates the suppressed, silent despair of a people repeatedly victimised as they search for inclusion and cultural identification.
movie_title: Bei qing cheng shi (A City of Sadness) (1989)

movie_review_blurb: Provides de Oliveira with a broad canvas to explore his recurring themes of doomed love, the relationship between image and reproduction, and cultural extinction.
Shyam Benegal creates a sublime and provocative examination of hypocrisy, economic disparity, and the social status of women in Ankur.
An evocative, richly textured, and deeply disturbing contemporary ballad on the pervasive nature of violence and the difficulty of assimilation.
movie_title: J'ai pas sommeil (I Can't Sleep) (I'm Not Sleepy) (1995)

movie_review_blurb: Cristi Puiu's The Death of Mr. Lazarescu is a thoughtful and incisive slice-of-life comedy on the impersonalization (and desensitization) of institutional health care.
A sublime and effervescent exposition on the interconnection between art and life, the foibles of rationalized, amoral behavior, and the innate recursiveness of human history.
movie_title: Genealogies of a Crime (Généalogies d'un crime) (1998)

movie_review_blurb: Perhaps the singularly most humbling and remarkably inspiring film I have ever seen in a long time on selflessness, compassion, instilling hope, and human decency.
A refreshingly optimistic, humorous, captivating, and deeply humanist portrait of perseverance and family.
...exposes the imbalancing entropy and transience of an existence bound in the underlying artifice of mercantile love.
movie_title: Sisters of the Gion (Gion no shimai) (1936)

movie_review_blurb: ...a bold and provocative allegory for the self-destructive cultural legacy of machismo, bravura, and ritualistic violence.
...a provocative and haunting portrait of man's eternal spiritual struggle against the indefinable nature of evil, sin, and corporeal existence.
movie_title: Mother Joan of the Angels (Matka Joanna od aniolów) (1961)

movie_review_blurb: ...a visually rigorous, uncompromising, and quietly affecting examination of the problem of illegal immigration.
movie_title: From the Other Side (De L'autre Cote) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: a distilled, lucid, and incisive cautionary tale of obdurate pride, self-righteous rationalization, and archaic traditions.
...an understatedly powerful document of a country at the cusp of profound change.
A darkly comic, delirious, and irreverent satire on aging, sexuality, and narcissism
...articulates a profound and compassionate anthem for a lost and marginalized generation foundering in the inertia of technology and modernization.
An understated, contemplative, and elegiac portrait on the ephemeral nature of time, youth, love, and existence.
Despite Assayas's admirable exploration of a difficult and complex subject... the film suffers from a meandering, preposterous, and schizophrenic plot.
The film serves as an incisive and affecting portrait of the uncalculated human toll of the painful, and often traumatic reconstruction of a war torn nation.
The film provocatively captures the unarticulated tragedy of estrangement, loneliness, and disconnection.
movie_title: Jeanne Dielman, 23 Quai du Commerce, 1080 Bruxelles (1975)

movie_review_blurb: ...a personal documentary of reconciliation and closure that is both honest, fearless, and profoundly inspiring.
An indelibly haunting, endlessly fascinating, and maddeningly abstruse composition on Pirandellian ambiguity and the inherent subjectivity of perspective.
movie_title: L'Hypothèse du tableau volé (The Hypothesis of the Stolen Painting) (1979)

movie_review_blurb: An understatedly provocative examination of crime, poverty, and marginalization in a culturally ingrained, codified society.
...a serenely contemplative and formally exquisite exposition on aesthetic philosophy, refinement, and spiritual unity.
...visually distilled, minimalist, and understated, yet compelling and profoundly expressive portrait of human struggle, perseverance, and survival.
an exquisite, deeply affecting, and provocative examination of filial duty, estrangement, guilt, and longing.
movie_title: The Day the Sun Turned Cold (1994)

movie_review_blurb: ...a singular, audacious, and iconic exposition on the malleability of reality, time, existence, and memory.
movie_title: L'année dernière à Marienbad (Last Year at Marienbad) (1961)

movie_review_blurb: One of the most meticulously designed and executed films.

There is brilliant interplaying and underplaying, of script, performers and direction which will raise howls of laughter from audiences, yet never descends on the screen to overdone mugging, pratfall and other heavy-handed devices normally employed.
The fast-moving 124-minute film engenders enormous suspense as the shark attacks a succession of people.
With political paternalism rampant at both extremes of the spectrum, Lucas is onto something. In any case, we'll know for sure in about a generation.
A delightful, satirical comedy-drama.

Stanley Kubrick's latest film takes the heavy realities of the 'do-your-thing' and 'law-and-order' syndromes, runs them through a cinematic centrifuge, and spews forth the commingled comic horrors of a regulated society.
This is a bawdy, stops-out, no-holds-barred story of a TV network that will, quite literally, do anything to get an audience.
Examines its subject matter with perception, depth, insight, humor and feeling
Producer-director Fred Zinnemann has blended all filmmaking elements into an excellent, handsome and stirring film version of A Man For All Seasons.
A daring film concept which in its special and technical effects has been superbly realized.
movie_title: Close Encounters of the Third Kind (1977)

movie_review_blurb: The biggest achievement here is the establishment of mood and time.

There are occasional flashes that the film may be patronizing the lower end of the blue-collar mentality, as much if not more than the characters who keep putting Rocky down on the screen. However, Avildsen is noted for creating such ambiguities.
Jack Nicholson stars in an outstanding characterization of Ken Kesey's asylum anti-hero, McMurphy, and Milos Forman's direction of a superbly-cast film is equally meritorious.
movie_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest (1975)

movie_review_blurb: A magnificent film. George Lucas set out to make the biggest possible adventure fantasy out of his memories of serials and older action epics, and he succeeded brilliantly.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode IV - A New Hope (1977)

movie_review_blurb: An excellent Sidney Poitier performance, and an outstanding one by Rod Steiger, overcome some noteworthy flaws to make In The Heat of the Night an absorbing contemporary murder drama.
movie_title: In the Heat of the Night (1967)

movie_review_blurb: Extremely handsome production values and a great supporting cast round out the virtues.
Travolta's characterization, given the script and directorial demands, is okay. It will please the already-committed; but it won't win him any new fans.
Excellent cast, headed by newcomer Richard Roundtree, may shock some audiences with heavy dose of candid dialog and situation.
Roman Polanski's American made film, first since Rosemary's Baby shows him again in total command of talent and physical filmmaking elements.
Gerald L. C. Copley has done a first rate adaptation of the true story of Joy Adamson, who with hubby George involuntarily domesticated several pet lions.
It's a powerful film and a terrific showcase for the versatility of star Robert De Niro.
The Paramount release has everything going for it.
Based on a Roald Dahl book, Nicholas Roeg's The Witches is a film surprisingly faithful to the creepiness of the original.
Despite its shortcomings, Tour of Duty is a striking film, even if it doesn't fit the conventions you typically associate with a documentary.
Joe Berlinger covers all the angles quite well in Whitey: United States of America v. James J. Bulger, a straight-forward court case documentary.
movie_title: Whitey: United States of America v. James J. Bulger (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The Keystone XL pipeline debate literally hits home in Above All Else, a compelling story about one's struggle to live simply.
FIlmmaker Khalo Matabane manages an amazing feat by making a documentary that's both in praise of Nelson Mandela, and tests some of the preconceived notions about him.

A fascinating follow-up to Never Sorry, Ai Weiwei: The Fake Case considers the implications of one's political actions in a protective state like China, and doubles down on letting one's voice be heard in spite of the consequences.
Veronica Mars is a delicious and fulfilling outing for those who remember the series fondly, and even those who are non-fans should be able to follow along for most of the fun.
112 Weddings is a real-life romantic tale that's funny, poignant, fascinating and true to life.
Walking with the Enemy is a decent war movie that while enjoyable at times, doesn't do anything to break the mould.
Cesar Chavez is a typical and topical biopic, but the performances, led by a very strong Michael Peña, should leave you satisfied.
Sacro GRA is a technically well-made film, but it may require audience members to be open-minded to enjoy it.
Strong performances and a straight-forward script allows Lee Daniels' The Butler to solidly deliver on expectations.
Everyday Rebellion offers mixed messages about the subtle nature of modern protest, but the characters trying to make the case are compelling enough to wish them well in their respective missions.
Advanced Style is a fun and sunny documentary about fashion mavens in their golden years, proving, as always, that age ain't nothing but a number.
Idris Elba and Taraji P. Henson are great actors, but No Good Deed is silly and cliché-riddled in spite of itself from beginning till end.

With solid performances and decent drama, Me and You isn't Bernardo Bertolucci's best, but it's an engaging and enjoyable enough film from a master of the craft. What it lacks in punch, it makes up for in effort.
Alive Inside is a charming and emotional documentary that dares us to think outside the box concerning the care and treatment of America's growing population of seniors.
Kirsten Stewart and Peyman Moaadi ably take center stage in the Gitmo drama Camp X-Ray, but do we need to be reminded that we're not that different again?

If you've seen a Christmas movie made in the last 30 or 40 years, then you've seen A Merry Friggin' Christmas. It's a Gatling gun of holiday movie clichés played out by a cast of characters that almost do a disservice to the term "broad stereotype."
Doctor Who's latest Christmas special, "Last Christmas," doesn't rock the boat, but it's a fun holiday caper that features Peter Capaldi at his best.
Being Canadian is a fun and humorous examination of what it means to be Canadian, even if it's sometimes wrapped up in its own cleverness.
Like his last feature Downloaded, Alex Winter impressively tackles the various issues surrounding the black market Silk Road.

Frightening and fascinating, The Nightmare takes a scary subject and puts you right into the mindset of the people suffering from it by treating this story as much as a horror movie as it does a documentary.
Chuck Norris vs Communism is part spy movie thriller, part comedic tribute to VHS that firmly makes a case for the literal transformative power of cinema.
Above and Below is an immersive viewing experience that requires patience and open-mindedness, but it's richly rewarding for those that make it though to the end.
For anyone interested in the notion of how belief can corrupt as well as save, or perhaps hold a more extreme atheistic view of any organized faith, then this is the documentary for you.
The Case Against 8 makes great history, but as a documentary it doesn't really break any new ground.

Predator does not just fuse different generic elements, it also plays on Schwarzenegger's star image, in particular by reversing his role in The Terminator by casting him as the human in conflict with the alien robot.
Based on a real-life Nazi operation, the film is a tense drama with performances that elevate the movie to the front rank of films set in concentration camps.
A predictable patchwork of forbidden romance, English arrogance, a gun given as a gift, suicide, corruption, deception, rising Indian nationalism and a short-lived chase through the jungle.
Entertainers bloom from nowhere, sing and then vanish - it's rather like an extended music video.
A predictable, undernourished love story.
movie_title: La tête en friche (My Afternoons with Margueritte) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A highly accessible and sharply drawn film.
movie_title: Sholem Aleichem: Laughing in the Darkness (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A heavy-handed attempt to sanctify one of the most dignified and uncompromising politicians and human rights champions of recent times.
A moderately ingratiating, none too probing and largely predictable essay on the way people fear and embrace their senior years.
I now pronounce you mildly amused!
Apocalypse is a clunker that encapsulates all the worst clichés of the genre, with none of the charm.
[A] small but cuddly film.

Screenwriter Dean Craig and director Frank Oz are not at all shy about possibly offending midgets, the elderly or the dead. From a hilariously insipid rambling eulogy to a naked man on the roof, this funeral turns into a demented upper-class riot.
A revelation in the history of nerds on film, Eagle vs. Shark is a sincere work that treats nerds as human beings, rather than punching bags.

Throwing a mentally impaired dude into a heist drama doesn't really add much. There are times when the audience will forget that Chris is disabled, partially because Gordon-Levitt isn't very persuasive.
It doesn't rank with recent Mexican art house gems like Amores Perros and Y Tu Mamá También, but it's a tough, little film with a point to make.
movie_title: Nadie Te Oye: Perfume de Violetas (Violet Perfume: Nobody Hears You) (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Tarnation is the naked, terrifying story of Caouette's extraordinarily messed-up childhood.
Like recent rom-com Friends with Benefits, it's the chemistry of the two leads that keeps it afloat. They just deserve better material to flirt around.
A modern, adult story that's both uproariously funny and touchingly real.
It's a harmless yarn that's as buttery as popcorn and as sweet as a choc top. And who doesn't like a trip to the candy bar via Europe?
The acting, period detail and luminous cinematography make up for some of the over-sentimentalised moments.
No-holds-barred humour, an up-for-anything all-star cast and a fast, madcap energy make this one of the best comedies you'll see in 2011.
Gross-out comedy big on cheap laughs, short on depth
Gleeks unite for song, dance and screams
Raunchy rom-com carried by chemistry
Low-key charmer saved by star power
Most entertaining doco of the year
movie_title: POM Wonderful Presents: The Greatest Movie Ever Sold (2011)

movie_review_blurb: It's not a bad film -- it just could have been a lot better.
Unfortunately, Cowboys and Aliens takes itself way too seriously to really ignite.
Faults aside, In Time is a great sci-fi yarn of our times.
It's rightly one of the big-ticket cinematic events of the year - don't miss it.
Australia needs more envelope-pushing comedies, but A Few Best Men doesn't deliver.

Wall-E and Finding Nemo director Andrew Stanton must shoulder the blame for this over-bloated disaster. It's impossible to care about the protagonists, played by the helplessly wooden Kitsch and Collins.
21 Jump Street proves that you can reinvent the wheel and pay homage to its past in one very funny package.
Something remarkable: a superhero movie that entertains, excites, explodes, and even takes time to examine itself, and the world in which we live in.
Visually stunning and delightfully bawdy, Dark Shadows is worth its return from the grave.
Radcliffe holds it together with a virtually wordless, but still expressive performance.
Despite some contrived plot points (the convenient pay-to-get-in house parties, for one), Not Suitable for Children is more than suitable because it doesn't treat viewers like children.

A keen knowledge of the events of the past films is required, but Nolan skilfully weaves the strands together in spectacular fashion so that the final result leaves you gripped to the seat long after the film has finished.
The Sapphires is often laugh-out-loud funny, constantly entertaining, and close to being a great Australian classic.
Looper is a dark, violent and surprisingly intelligent edge-of-your-seat thriller with a similar feel to sci-fi trips like Inception and In Time.
For the most part, On The Road is on the right track. All it needs is slightly more direction.

Shamelessly cheesy, drawn-out and over-the-top as it is, The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn - Part 1 is big, bombastic popcorn entertainment that knows exactly what the fans want, and delivers it in epic style.
There's great potential here, but the execution is far too clunky.
While social media is increasingly coming under the microscope for engendering insecurity among young people, cinema is yet to deliver a truly chilling meditation on its insidious impact.
An intriguing look at a creatively charged period of art history.
movie_title: Troublemakers: The Story of Land Art (2016)

movie_review_blurb: There's a surprisingly heartfelt message behind the thuggish bravado.
May be the best straightforward California-noir since Robert Altman's The Player.
That is the sign of a great storyteller - when they work, not in surprises, but in giving you exactly what you didn't know you wanted.
movie_title: The Boy And The Beast (Bakemono No Ko) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: I gather there is something to this film that I lack the patience to appreciate in its storytelling, but I cannot for the life of me meditate on the occurrences like the film seems like it wants me to.

Everything from the angle of the shot to the speed of the editing projects an end visual that feels like you're either on Toothless' back or you get an outsider perspective of just how fast he's flying.
Fantastic in the technical aspects of cinematography and especially sound-mixing. Toby Jones is as reliable as he always is and the movie never really bores you.
The picture isn't perfect, but its flaws come not only at the attempt to grandly succeed, but by breaking ground in rarely visited territories.
I wouldn't say you need a strong stomach to handle some of the bits, but you certainly need to be able to have a sense of humor about some things that are legitimately awful.

Every aspect of the film seeks to make an emotional connection with the audience via specificity, and thanks to masterful work from Lonergan as writer and director and phenomenal performances from the entire ensemble cast, it is an absolute triumph.

McGregor's Jesus is one of contemplation, introspection, and quiet frustration and his Demon is nearly an exact mirror of Jesus himself, representing the potential for Him to carve out a different path-one in which he denies his Father.
Nichols' attention to detail, willingness to trust his audience, and desire to tackle multiple social themes of the time at once result in a rich, rewarding viewing experience.

The movie is full of scenes that feel like this is the one where the film's really gonna take off, but inevitably they all end before hitting that point. It's cinematic blue balls. Lots of exciting build-up to, well, lots of frustration.
It's a little on the nose, but the film is realized with such sincerity, such vivid imagery, and such raw emotion that it's hard to fault. Just remember to bring Kleenex. Lots of it.
A firecracker of a script that zips from scene to scene with cheeky dialogue and a sense of urgency, with a strong feminist undercurrent permeating throughout.
It's a nice movie. And sometimes, nice is enough.

You've never really seen a movie like Colossal. It's an alcoholism drama. It's a dark comedy. It's a kaiju movie. It's all of these things in one, and thanks to a tremendous balance of tone from Vigalondo, it succeeds far more than it fails.

There's nothing wrong with telling the story of an unlikeable guy who, over a journey of self-discovery, comes to turn his life around and realize what a jerk he's been but there's a fine line to walk between unlikable and irredeemable.
There's nothing wrong with old fashioned if done the right way, but 'The Promise' feels like the kind of film that's out of date.
'Strange Weather' is a fairly solid chronicle of the grieving process, but an even better performance showcase for the tremendous Holly Hunter.

Gorgeous imagery pondering our existence can only sustain so much of a film's runtime when the thematic undercurrent is this simple. Even the most devoted Malick fan may find himself or herself bored to tears by Voyage of Time: Life's Journey.

Through Stewart and Hoult's powerful performances and Doremus' delicate direction, Equals speaks to human relationships in a way that's intimately familiar, romantic, and, yes, emotionally gut-punching.

Watching Norman Lear: Just Another Version of You is like getting a lesson on the history of television and a therapy session all in one go, and boy what a delight it is to spend a couple of hours with this sincere, flawed, funny pioneer.
movie_title: Norman Lear: Just Another Version of You (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The immigrant story is one that has been told countless times over, but director John Crowley's moving and funny Brooklyn brings a degree of empathy to this particular tale that is rare.
Villeneuve pulls no punches-it's refreshingly frank, and while it may not be a "feel-good" movie, it's a film that you're not likely to shake too quickly after it ends.
Funny, sweet, and wholly unique, Swiss Army Man is an insane strange bird of a film that is not to be missed.
If you remove the historic importance of these two characters, Southside with You still mostly works as a simple love story between a pair of intellectuals striving for greatness.
Andrew Neel has crafted what could be his first major crossover hit, as he layers the film with a sense of darkness and dread that is wildly effective but never drowns out the rest of the picture.
It's nothing new, and it falls short of profundity, but it's emotionally genuine, warmly funny, and charming as all get-out. Sometimes, that's enough.
Anchored by an exquisitely crafted script and fine-tuned aesthetics, Indignation offers a compelling twist on the coming-of-age genre with intelligence and wit to spare.

Black and Bernstein understand what it is that makes Linklater so curious, and in chronicling his career in such a clear and entertaining way, they've put together a worthwhile and winning portrait of a very special filmmaker.

The Fundamentals of Caring is beyond predictable, landing every single beat you're expecting it to land, and yet it's all made engaging and enjoyable thanks to the warmth and rascal-like humor of Rudd and a funny, complicated turn by Roberts.
The Free World is a film that doesn't know what it wants to be, and its hodgepodge of tones and focus result in a frustrating viewing experience.
If someone decided to adapt a series of cat posters into a feature film, it might resemble something like Captain Fantastic.
The key to 'The Witch' is that director Robert Eggers deals in dread, not scares. The audience is constantly watching in trepidation, not sure where the film will go next.
One part thriller, one part political drama plus a splash of satire makes for a fine, if sobering, cocktail.
'City of Tiny Lights' is a disappointing and somewhat boring drama that rests almost entirely on Ahmed's captivating performance.

Look, if you want to make home movies with your friends and family that's fine. But if you're going to release them as feature films, at least respect viewers enough to try to make something that makes sense.
In less talented hands this could have been one long promo for Justin Timberlake: The Brand. In the hands of Demme, it's pure art.
Those fascinated by crises of faith or stories about religion will find stuff to chew on, but as a feature film it leaves something to be desired.
The winning performances from Dinklage and Fanning mixed with Morano's confident handle behind the camera make for a most intriguing entry into the post-apocalyptic genre.
This is a movie driven by filmmaking, and [Debra] Granik's skill behind the camera drives a lot of the narrative forward. That and, of course, [Harcourt] McKenzie's performance.

Nevertheless, thanks to a wonderfully sensitive and bold performance from [Elise] Fisher and some standout work from Burnham behind the camera, Eighth Grade is ultimately an effective-if not exactly revelatory-watch.
Wildlife digs into the complexity of these dynamics, buoyed by a powerhouse performance from Carey Mulligan. And along the way it announces Paul Dano as a bona fide filmmaker.

Barry is much more about race and identity in America than what our nation's first African-American president did when he was in college. It's a thoughtful, intelligent film that also happens to be mighty entertaining.

Three Identical Strangers is shocking, thrilling, and wildly entertaining, but it's also incredibly moving, leaving a lasting impression that you won't easily shake. I have a feeling this is a film we're going to be talking about for a long time to come.
Blindspotting doesn't have all the answers, and it doesn't even really attempt to give them, but it does provide a road to understanding through empathy.

The film's attempts to flesh out Felt's personal life fall flat and the story has a bit of trouble sticking the landing. Regardless, it's a fascinating story with a surprisingly strong tie to what's currently happening in the U.S. government.
movie_title: Mark Felt: The Man Who Brought Down the White House (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The film is an incredibly sweet affair, and although it's almost drowning in pleasantries to the point that it lacks much drama, Serkis does an admirable job behind the camera.

No doubt Joe and Rose's stories are interesting and compelling, but there persists this nagging feeling that their characters are somewhat co-opting this story... and Hostiles tests the patience of its audience.

What's it feel like to be put up on a pedestal for simply surviving a horrific event, with an inability to walk as a permanent reminder of that trauma? That's what Stronger explores and it doesn't shy away from the darker realities of life.

Sorkin approaches his directorial debut confidently and, thankfully, with ambition, juggling complex exposition with a an exciting visual style. Molly's Game is highly entertaining and positively delightful watch.
Professor Marston and the Wonder Women is a terrific story of finding acceptance, challenging the norm, and debating ideas in an intelligent instead of belligerent manner.
It's basically Chronicle meets The Breakfast Club. In order to fully become Power Rangers, these kids must care more about others than themselves.
Before the Flood isn't simply interested in showing how terrible everything is. It also does a fantastic job of highlighting solutions for climate change, both short-term and long-term.

An Inconvenient Truth had a pertinent message, but was delivered in the driest of manners. An Inconvenient Sequel has an even more pertinent message, but is thankfully packaged in a more effective, fascinating film.
movie_title: An Inconvenient Sequel: Truth To Power (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It's a rousing, engaging chronicle of British politics, and also a surprisingly moving story about great leadership.
It's honest and sweet, but one can't help but think that focusing the narrative a tad would have resulted in a more satisfying watch.
