Helms' Griswold is a dangerous, moronic maniac, and the filmmakers' disdain for him rubs off on the audience.
Welcome to the End of the World, Adam Sandler-style.
For a small movie, "Ant-Man" has a lot going on. Rudd makes it work.
Good show, lads.
"Chappie" is all over the place, employing a cloying, "Patch Adams"-like sentimentality and abandoning logic at every turn.
For a movie that pretends to address issues of what it means to be human, "Ted 2" is soulless at its core, a pure product.
"San Andreas" never pretends to be any less subtle than the Rock's physique. It's a hulking mass of wanton destruction, and a stupid-fun carnival of carnage.
An important film to see for parents, students and anyone involved with academia.
For a movie about a 106-year-old - albeit one trapped in the body of a 29-year-old - "The Age of Adaline" doesn't have a lot of wisdom.
A so-so movie about an extraordinary athlete.
If it has a point about the way we treat people online, it's lost in an illogical ghost story that never bothers explaining itself.
Baumbach plays with universal themes about the uncertainty of aging, the elusive nature of "cool" and the acceptance that comes with settling down ...
The real stars of these films are the bonkers action setpieces, and "Furious 7" achieves new high points in that department.
You may not have missed them, but Vinnie, E, Turtle and Drama are back, as empty and self-centered as ever, in the aimless, vapid Entourage movie.
"Risen" was never meant as anything but a tool for the converted. Talk about preaching to the choir.
Hood keeps the action tense throughout this nail-biter, which unfolds like a taut stage play. It offers no easy answers, only difficult questions about following orders and the cost of war.
No one is confusing "Gods of Egypt" with strong storytelling. But for a mindless whir of crazy visuals, you can do a lot worse.
Johnson brings the funny. Underneath all that muscle, a comedy star is wrestling to get out, and he's finally emerged.
There's a rhythm to these things, and screenwriter Chris Frisina has certainly watched his share of late-night cable TV thrillers.
It's a galloping victory.
"Maggie's Plan" is Gerwig's show, and once again she proves to be one of the screen's most engaging presences.
Sometimes video games are best left as video games.
As the illusions mount, they don't amount to much, leading up to a big finale that piles on the improbabilities and quietly sweeps them under the rug.
"Weiner" is a thorough examination of modern politics, the 24-hour news cycle and the grind of the campaign trail.
"Out of the Shadows" is by no means a really good pizza, but if you liked the last film, it's worth a slice.
movie_title: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Out of the Shadows (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Clarke's sparkle is similar to when Julia Roberts graced the screen in "Pretty Woman." Get used to her, she'll be around for awhile.
As a satire of modern pop stardom, "Popstar: Never Stop Never Stopping" could use a little more pop.
Stillman doesn't upend the Austen formula, he burrows into it and embraces all its trappings. The snappy dialogue, meanwhile, rewards a finely tuned ear and will thrill all lovers of language.
Lanthimos doesn't deliver all the way, but he sticks his landing mightily and whets appetites for whatever he decides to do next.
There's no spark, and everyone lumbers through the motions. The apocalypse, it turns out, is deadly dull.
Burton had the right idea sitting this one out; one trip to "Wonderland" was plenty.

Flynn looks at the history of cinema, from the earliest tent exhibitions to huge IMAX presentations, focusing on the projectionists locked away in tiny booths in the backs of rooms who made it all happen.
"Genius" deals with the creative ego, its trappings and the need everyone has for an editor.
The film simmers and builds until it boils over in an explosive climax. And it shows how far people will go just to be able to cling to some semblance of hope.
Call it a civil bore.
For what it is, "The Shallows" works.
Awards material it's not, but the movie knows its intentions and audience, and cooks everything up into a satisfying meal.
Ross delivers a warm, humorous, enlightening family drama marked by strong performances ...
Lin's flashy sense of stylized grit is lost in a sea of sci-fi noise as "Beyond" becomes a monotonous blur of space babble and battles.
It sits in the middle, wanting to blaze a new trail but haunted by the ghosts of its past.

Even Gerwig, who could light up a darkened cavern simply with her walk, is wasted under Solondz' mirthless direction. She shuffles along with her shoulders slumped, like all characters in Solondz' movies.
A scathing indictment of bureaucracy and corporate greed wrapped up in the guise of a frenzied thriller, "A Monster with a Thousand Heads" will be too close for comfort for some.
movie_title: A Monster With A Thousand Heads (Un Monstruo de Mil Cabezas) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The movie goes for a bawdy, "outrageous" vibe and big laughs, which it lands less than half the time.
movie_title: Mike and Dave Need Wedding Dates (2016)

movie_review_blurb: "The Nice Guys" flies high on the chemistry between Gosling and Crowe, and Black gives them plenty to chew on. It's a gourmet summer treat. Nice, guys.
The film is as loud and busy as expected from modern cartoons. But there's nothing deeper at play, no clever animal insights, and nothing that makes good on that great title.
"Swiss Army Man" leaves an impression, but can't complete its job. Like Manny, it's full of hot air.
Mostly it's more of the same from this stalled series. It's time someone purges "The Purge."

The film is an investigative thriller that unravels the deep web of lies, threats and deceit that festers in the dark corners of the internet, and shows how online behavior can have damaging, real-world implications.
"The Legend of Tarzan" is no jungle boogie, but it's a decent swing.
As a character, the BFG is a wondrous creation, and Rylance does a magnificent job bringing him to life.
Instead of big fireworks, "The Phenom" offers low-key character moments. It's a small film with a lot of insight.

There's no denying the beauty of Refn's images, even if his puerile instincts are at odds with his obvious pretensions. Those who cry it's shallow and ugly won't be wrong; others will love it for those very reasons.
The movie grossly overestimates the audience's sympathy for a murderous thug and its interest in the morality of international banking.
A sensuous and thought-provoking adult drama dealing with temptation, sexuality and carnal desires.
As a testament to the power of music, the bond of brotherhood and the boundless possibilities of youth, "Sing Street" just plain works.
Bateman knows his fractured family well, but "Fang" doesn't give him enough to chew on. The characters are all scarred, but the film doesn't leave a mark.
There's an honesty in what Gold writes and the way he writes it, which is why his words have so much impact. The film has a similar impact to one of his reviews.

There's no pop to the story, no excitement; instead of a Williams concert, it's like hearing his songs faintly in the background on a diner jukebox. There's more punch in an obituary of the singer than there is here.
"Kill Your Friends" goes to some ugly places, but it keeps a sturdy sense of rhythm.
It's a big fat Greek dud.
The heavyweight title bout between Batman and Superman is a smash to the senses, the same way being tossed around in a rollover car accident would jolt one's system.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: With this hapless entry, even fans of the series will have their allegiance tested.

Showalter, whose 2005 romantic comedy "The Baxter" was similarly kindhearted, handles the material with tenderness and care, and never lets it devolve into meanness the way it might in the hands of another director.
Nichols has earned the right to take big leaps. Even if he doesn't stick the landing, it's a thrill watching him try. He, too, is something special.
Hit-or-miss director Atom Egoyan is way off here. He telegraphs the story's arc early, and screenwriter Benjamin August relies heavily on happenstance to move the story along.
It's a good Christian film that plays to its audience and preaches the importance of neighborly values.
Taken as a straightforward movie, "Knight of Cups" is an indecipherable mess. Taken as a piece of nonlinear visual poetry, "Knight of Cups" is still an indecipherable mess.

Winstead gives a strong performance as a captive who never gives up her fight. Goodman strikes a fine balance between nurturing caregiver and frightening captor, even if, to the detriment of the story, his end game is never really made clear.
An efficient wartime dramedy about middle-aged restlessness and the bubbles we build to distract ourselves from real life.
It's rarely exciting or suspenseful, and some of the digital effects are also reminiscent of a 1980s action movie level.
"Zootopia" is a delight: It's cute and clever, smart and sophisticated, with plenty to offer children and adults.

Though it aims for heroism, Edwards' story doesn't have a dramatic enough arc to be truly inspirational. It's not about winning, it's an ode to participation, which isn't enough for it to get off the ground.
It's good to have Pee-wee back, and he makes this unexpected "Holiday" a joyous one.
The Witch" isn't typical gorehound material; it has an art film prestige and a commitment to period authenticity.
"The Boss" never feels like more than a series of bawdy, R-rated sketches held together by bubble gum and masking tape.
Hardcore Henry doesn't just get under your skin, it gets behind your eyeballs and uses your head as its own cockpit. For hardcore thrills, Henry is your guy.
Do mom a favor and skip it.
A house divided against itself cannot stand. But in the case of Captain America: Civil War, a divided house brings out the best in this supersized superhero franchise.
[Saulnier] has a gift for creating nail-biting tension and gets superb performances from his cast, but storywise he paints himself into a corner from which he can't escape.
"Mother's Day" is not a tribute to mothers. It's an insult to everyone.
Core fans used to the duo's style and humor will be pleased, others need not press start.
At least now we have an answer to the question, "Who's the dullest franchise of them all?"
You always trust Hanks, and he makes this "Hologram" feel real.
"Mr. Right" is very, very, very wrong.
Budreau, who stages several breathtaking scenes of Baker playing against the vast open sky during a visit to his parents' farm in Oklahoma, successfully gets to the root of his subject.
Writer-director-star Don Cheadle gives a towering performance that the film simply can't keep up with; he's truly on his own, which is perhaps the way Davis would have wanted it.
"Elvis and Nixon" plays with history, but never takes itself too seriously. Elvis and Nixon would have gotten a kick out of it.
The cast has a natural chemistry and the shop has an authentic feel. Even as things get preachy, the quips keep customers coming through the door.
Imagine "Porky's" as an intelligent character study and you're on the right path.
"Krisha" is a stone cold stunner.
Accept "The Invitation" and don't ask any more questions.
A film that will be celebrated, and rightly so, as one of the year's best family films. It's the rare remake that gets things right, and Favreau makes this "Book" a genuine page-turner.
Writer-director Cynthia Mort focuses on Simone's late-career relationship with her nurse-turned-manager, and isn't able to branch out and grasp the story of Simone's art or her impact.
Boseman is at times mesmerizing, living up to the gargantuan task of playing the American soul legend. If only the movie were as good as he is.
If Sherlock Holmes truly is the world's most keen detective, surely he would have sniffed out that this film was a stinker.
"The Purge: Anarchy" is more in line with what people going to a "Purge" movie would want out of a "Purge" movie.
First-time filmmaker Kevin Tancharoen struggles to flesh out the 10 characters we meet during their freshman year at PA.
For guitar geeks, the sight of Page, Edge and White together in one room will be enough. Others, however, can't help but wish it might have gotten a little louder.
The film is part romance, part drama, part Seattle travelogue, with Washington emerging as the only true winner. Along with the benefactors of the movie's copious product placements, that is.
There are probably worse ways to go out than being devoured by Fox... but the film squanders all the fun from what could have been a hilarious, gore-filled romp.

The movie then becomes one of those murder mysteries where everyone is a suspect, and the murderer himself is the least likely candidate of all. Dispelling all logic, you should be able to figure out this whodunit in the opening minutes.
The fact that Bana is a bit of a cold fish and real sparks never really ignite between he and McAdams, who is 10 years his junior, doesn't help matters.
You've seen alien invasion flicks before, and you've seen more than your share of summer blockbusters. But you've never seen anything quite like District 9.
Viewers know the gotcha is coming not only because they've been groomed to expect a third-act left turn in movies like this, but because the film's characters won't stop talking about it.
Beyond the high-stakes game of cat and mouse, the film explores the mysterious relationship between humans and dolphins and the unexplainable connection between our two species.
The film rests on Furhman's shoulders, and she's up to the task.
After it's over, it quickly vanishes from memory, and viewers are on to the next transaction.
A simplistic message movie boasting computer animation well below the industry standard.
I Love You, Man is a success; it's Fight Club with hugs, not fists.
The series reboot is much the same, but it's easily the most effective -- and scary -- entrant in the franchise.
Notorious is a game of dress-up, the Greatest Hits version of Biggie's life. But in the end, it fails to present a convincing argument of why we should care.
Now that's horror.
Saw VI doesn't come close to reigniting the spark of the original, but at least it approaches coherence, which is more than can be said for the last several installments of the series.
Harry Potter needn't call time out on his Quidditch game, and Edward Cullen can stick to his beauty rest.
movie_title: Cirque du Freak: The Vampire's Assistant (2009)

movie_review_blurb: It's a cute, touchy-feely crowd pleaser that wants nothing more than to wrap audiences in a warm holiday embrace. In a sense, it achieves that goal, but it is overly sentimental in a Lifetime movie kind-of-way.
Saw 3D is the dumbest and most illogical entry in the Saw series -- quite an accomplishment, given that the Saw movies are the dumbest, most illogical series of horror films of the millennium.
This is a date-night fright fest that delivers the goods, and will have you checking behind the door when you go to bed at night all over again.
This feels like a natural end for the Jackass franchise. It's been a great run, but nobody wants to see Grandpa Knoxville get toppled over by a speeding shopping cart.
It aims for comfort food, but ends up with leftovers.
The film tells a devastating story that couldn't be more relevant to our times, who we are in real life versus the way we present ourselves online.
The film's look can't overcome all its shortcomings, but it helps them go down easier than its title.
movie_title: Legend of the Guardians: The Owls of Ga'Hoole (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Takers is a slick heist film, but that's all it is.
It's a crafty action flick with a pristine cast that works, ever so briefly, as a wish-fulfillment fantasy.
That those blemishes begin to disappear each time her kids learn from her teachings offers a somewhat disturbing statement on the value of physical beauty.
An insane fantasy for rich people.
The kitties and puppies are cute to look at, no doubt, but your average cat on YouTube is far more charming than anything in this kitty litter.
movie_title: Cats & Dogs: The Revenge of Kitty Galore (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Sure, the film's reality may be saccharine, but for a non-computer animated, non-3D kid's film, we'll take it.
She's Out of My League doesn't answer the question of whether a 10 would go for a 5, but rather if audiences are willing to settle for a 5.
If there's a message in all this, it's buried in blood splatter. Which is fine, but makes The Crazies more disappointing than if it had less lofty goals.
Benicio Del Toro pulls off a nifty trick in The Wolfman: He makes turning into a werewolf look as dull as doing your taxes.
"Collision Course" won't alter the trajectory of history, but as an entertaining diversion, it does its job.
I's a bit like a trip to the gym on a flat tire.
This is purely gutter, fanboy, Cheez Whiz cinema, but Alexander delivers the goods.
Billy Corgan, leader of the Smashing Pumpkins and the Gloomy Gus of the 1990s alternative-rock movement, emotes plenty in the band's documentary If All Goes Wrong.
movie_title: Smashing Pumpkins: If All Goes Wrong (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A riotous comedy from director David Wain.
A mishmash of half-baked ideas, loud special-effects and disjointed imagery.
Even fans of good, old-fashioned, onscreen torture will find themselves rolling their eyes at the twists and turns in this impossibly convoluted story.
The Farrellys, who with There's Something About Mary helped lay the groundwork for the mixture of raunchiness and heart that Judd Apatow has perfected, seem painfully dated here.
Directed by Seth Gordon, the film illuminates and draws you into a subculture you never knew existed and makes you genuinely care about its characters.
movie_title: The King of Kong: A Fistful of Quarters (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Thornton and Sarandon should have their Oscars repossessed, or at least temporarily revoked, for appearing in this insipid comedy.
It works, and has the makings of a cult comedy to-be.
Michael Myers is back. And no, you still shouldn't care.
Smith is worth watching; the movie is not.
[Director Cain] stops short of calling Osama bin Laden a Mormon sympathizer, but maybe that'll be on the DVD.
It courts its audience with a warm story about lost loves and paths not chosen, and it boasts an array of strong performances from its top-notch ensemble.
Knocked Up is full of huge laughs and witty pop culture banter but also offers insightful and honest explorations of marriage, relationships, friendship and parenthood.

There is some inspired camera work during some of the performance sequences, but none of the performances themselves stick. It's a shame when a film about the power of music doesn't contain one memorable song.

The Condemned attempts to redeem itself with some late-inning moralizing that only cheapens the proceedings; if you're going to brandish as many guns as The Condemned does, at least stick to 'em in the end.
In the end, Just My Luck is light, fluffy and as quickly forgettable as a tossed-aside horoscope.
Alfie begins and ends by asking, 'What's it all about?' Unfortunately, it's a question the filmmakers never bother to answer.
A laughable -- or rather, unlaughable -- excuse for a film.
Superbad falls short of teen classic status. What a super-shame.
Every Thanksgiving needs a turkey, and this year's comes wrapped in a lacy bustier.
A maddening epic with a towering, bravura performance from star Daniel Day-Lewis, There Will Be Blood will rattle your brain for weeks, even months after you see it.
It's an unfortunate ending for a once-great screen character who deserves to be known for more than the waste he laid to others.
It is a misfire, a silly and borderline absurd story that cannot excuse its twists and turns with the simple 'a true story' declaration that opens the film.
Flashy but assured, the film is a controlled exercise in style that toes the line but never feels over-the-top. In a word, RocknRolla rocks.
Go ahead, dance it out.
The good news: Beverly Hills Chihuahua is not the apocalypse-signaling, cultural abomination its trailers make it out to be. The bad news: That's pretty much the best thing that can be said about it.
A cliché-riddled, warm and fuzzy, small-town sports drama.
Say this for Faris: Even though The House Bunny may be, she's not -- dumb.
There's a thin line between jeans that are well worn and jeans that are ratty and used up, and Traveling Pants 2 crosses that line.
movie_title: The Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants 2 (2008)

movie_review_blurb: As a testament to one of the few bands that actually warrants the 3D concert film treatment, U2 3D rattles and hums like no other.
That dinosaur looks like it's popping off the screen! Cool!
movie_title: Journey to the Center of the Earth (2008)

movie_review_blurb: As bad as a severe case of the Mondays.

Not that You Don't Mess with the Zohan is meant to be taken seriously, nor is it meant to be an intelligent discussion of world politics. But even as a zany comedy whose backdrop kinda-sorta happens to have some heft to it, it falters.
movie_title: You Don't Mess With the Zohan (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The film is far from an intelligent commentary on America's race relations...but at a time when race is at the forefront of the American discussion, it presents the topic in a way at which we can laugh.
movie_title: Harold & Kumar Escape from Guantanamo Bay (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Forgetting Sarah Marshall is a lazy, second-hand offering from the Apatow crude-but-sweet assembly line.
No one's saying George Clooney isn't a dashing fellow. But his charm and affability only go so far in Leatherheads.

A large, talented cast is mostly wasted in Welcome Home Roscoe Jenkins, one of those movies Hollywood cranks out to celebrate the down-home charms of small town life by exposing the vapidity of showbiz and celebrity.
It's so bad even Carmen Electra should be embarrassed.
For a comic genius, Mike Myers sure aims low.
"Wish I Was Here" sets up some big moments but doesn't follow through on them, emotionally or otherwise. Like its title implies, it's absent at its own party.
[A] mixed bag of a country music comeback fable.
Let's have a toast for Vince Vaughn, shall we?
Director Courtney Solomon doesn't know how to shoot action; his herky-jerk style is a constant distraction and never lets momentum build.
Teller and Woodley hum together, and the movie does their performances justice.
The performance at the center just isn't up to the job.
The savvy wit and inspiration on display in the first film is absent in this dumbed-down, warmed over retread. Consider its ass kicked.
As "The Conjuring" progresses, the scares don't register beyond standard issue horror gotchas. They're as telegraphed as the musical cues alerting you something spooky is about to happen.
Refn seems to have some issues he needs to work out, and "Only God Forgives" does as well. If it doesn't quite get all the way there, at least it's an interesting mess.
Friendship, family and breasts: Sometimes that's all you need.
It packs plenty of laughs, which is ultimately what you want out of a stand-up film.
"The Hangover Part III" is a more proper follow-up to the original than "Part II," and Phillips gives his characters a proper send off.
As the body count mounts, the movie begins to spin out of control, but Shannon and Vromen don't let it derail. Their focus keep things from melting down.
The movie's clichés would be more acceptable if the characters were better drawn, but there's not a memorable one in the bunch.

It never feels real, and its only saving grace is that it clocks in at a mercifully short 90 minutes, which is just about the amount of time you need to realize you never want to see these characters ever again.
"Mud" unfolds at its own pace, revealing its story in slivers. The performances are outstanding, especially from Sheridan, who plays tough, sweet, vulnerable and confused with equal conviction.
Raimi set the bar high, and if Alvarez can't quite rise to his level, he overcompensates by drowning everything in blood. It's overkill, but in this case that's not such a bad thing.
A goofball teenage sci-fi romance, "The Host" is an End of Days parable that seems like it was written at a slumber party.
It might not make you a fan of One Direction, but it will certainly make you understand the group, which is the job of any good documentary.
Twohy is trying to do something with his original character. It's just not clear what that something is anymore. Maybe it's time this franchise fades to black for good.

It's tentative in its intentions and afraid to push all the way with its premise. It is not sharp enough as a comedy, and when it tries to shift gears and become a romance, it is unconvincing in its machinations.
The film isn't worthy of De Niro's stature, in the gangster sub-genre or otherwise.
"Earth to Echo" recalls - but doesn't live up to - films like "Super 8" and "Stand By Me," stories of youth, innocence and the Summer That Changed Everything.
"Evil" doesn't shy away from grisly images. But the scares don't last ...
Feels more like an extended riff than a fully fleshed-out film.
movie_title: A Million Ways to Die in the West (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The laughs are sporadic and the supposedly tender moments are as heartwarming as a Hot Pocket.
Director Camille Delamarre does a sloppy job of piecing everything together, and nobody on screen seems invested in what is going on. The feeling from the audience is mutual.
There are grittier nature documentaries out there, but "Bears" is simple and effective, and delivered with that friendly Disney touch. Its intent is to make you say, "awww," and it does its job well.
Two and-a-half hours may seem like a lot for an Indonesian crime saga, but "The Raid 2" has a sweeping scope that justifies its running time. And it will knock you out.
A half hour, four hours, two days after walking away from it you might still flashback to its seductive, neon-lit, dayglow world.
Horror movie-gruesome and pumped up like a 'roid rage, "Sabotage" is an abrasive, ugly exercise in macho nonsense.
"That Awkward Moment" wants to be part "American Pie" and part "Swingers." It doesn't get there, but thanks to its cast, watching it try has its moments.
[Most] of the movie is a wash of buddy cop clichés and double crosses that aren't worth the cocktail napkin they were jotted on.
Stick with your memories of Rocky Balboa and Jake La Motta, because "Grudge Match" isn't a fight worth fighting.
"Machete Kills" is barely a movie. It's an inside joke wrapped in a fanboy fantasy, pieced together through a haze of ironic detachment.
You see "Runner Runner's" hand before it's played, and there's nothing to keep you playing.
Gordon-Levitt's characters feel real and "Don Jon" is a convincing, authentic, funny, modern romance.
Metallica is as fierce and intense as ever, and the greatest hits set the band performs is a barrage of heavy riff-age that captures the band at its most vital.
It's a fresh update on an old story made relevant by a strong cast.
"Olympus Has Fallen" goes through plenty of familiar motions, but does them well enough that it gets away with it. There's a reason movies like this die hard.
Yes, it's cheese, but it's good cheese.
The best thing that can be said about "Safe Haven" is there is a cute romance in there somewhere.
The Woman in Black is your standard-issue ghost story, gussied up in period garb to make it look like a prestige picture.
"Haywire" isn't a by-the-numbers action vehicle, it's a crafty thriller that works to undo beat-em-up clichés. In short, it's a livewire.
It wants to be a charming, down-home good time, but it struggles to hit the right notes.
Downey's career is something of a game of shadows, but it's one still worth playing, for now.
movie_title: Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The disjointed, undercooked sequel to the Oscar-winning 2006 hit aims to tell life lessons and celebrate pop music, but this would-be toe-tapper is curiously out of step.
Joost and Schulman sustain a consistent sense of dread, playing with our own fears of things that go bump in the night.

It's also a fight movie that knows all the fight movie cliches and doesn't shy away from embracing them wholeheartedly. But it hits its marks and hits them well, and feels fresh even as it traffics so deeply in the familiar.
Chronicle puts a fresh, invigorating spin on the superhero origin story, a tale Hollywood spins again and again (and again).

Farrell is all darting eyes, facial ticks and macho confidence. He never goes over the top, he's not a showy actor, but he's clearly relishing his role and eating it up with abandon. He makes this a Night to remember.
The movie gets the beats and rhymes down pat, but the life part is a little messy. Oh well, two out of three ain't bad.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Horrible Bosses takes a dark premise -- three buddies band together to off their bosses -- and rings it for a solid, steady stream of laughs.
Director Thomas Bezucha lingers too long on side plots and doesn't give the film emotional resonance.
Everyone loves an anti-hero, but usually there's something redeeming about the character that makes you want to root for them in the end. Not so much in Bad Teacher.
It's fun at times, if a bit over-dramatic and a lot over-the-top. But by the end, you're ready for it to be over.
In Something Borrowed, Kate Hudson looks exhausted, as if she is as tired of wading through another one of her feckless duds as we are of watching them.
What the movie lacks in genuine insight it makes up for in what fans really want: gazing shots at the Biebz whipping his hair back and forth.
The 3D Concert Movie is by and large for Gleeks only.
A big, sloppy, loud, grating mess of a movie.
"The Five-Year Engagement" doesn't always work - some of the supporting characters' storylines feel clipped, and the improvised bits could afford to be tightened - but the trip to the altar pays off.
"Safety" can't sustain its own offbeat energy. By the end, even Aubrey Plaza would roll her eyes at it.
All sorts of blockheaded action thrillers rolled into one, with occasional mentions of "flash drives" so you know it's not actually a script from 1986.
"Parker" should have stayed parked.
Like the film's shady mayor, "Broken City" is a little too slick for its own good.
"Gangster Squad" talks tough and hits hard, but it is a victim of its own brute force.
People in Hollywood need to work and surely "The Collection" created a lot of jobs, but there must be a better way.
Good riddance "Twilight," may it be an eternity before you're relaunched or rebooted.
movie_title: The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn Part 2 (2012)

movie_review_blurb: It's fun for awhile, but it's not a video game you'll come back to once you set down the controller.
Sandler's Berger is the most loutish, annoying character he's come up with since "Little Nicky." Nicky came from hell; viewers of "That's My Boy" will feel like they're in it.
It feels like a project that was pitched for the CW but watered down for Nickelodeon audiences. In the end, everyone loses.
"Here Comes the Boom" is so full of clichés from other, better movies that it is almost plays like a parody of an underdog tale.
The one thing that comes across is Neeson's character really likes fighting Albanians.
"Pitch Perfect" doesn't take itself any more seriously than it has to, and has plenty of fun both sending up and celebrating its subject matter.
When Spike Lee fails he fails big, and he goes down in flames with "Red Hook Summer."
It's an average Will Ferrell comedy, nothing more.
Bendjelloul mixes modern footage of Detroit with archival and animated images, and the shots of Rodriguez marching through his home turf help viewers understand what makes him tick.
"Part of Me" is more electronic press kit than fly-on-the-wall documentary.
There's still a marketplace for a smart, well-crafted cat-and-mouse thriller. But "Alex Cross" isn't it.
The scares are cheap, but they're frequently effective, the same way that if you're hungry junk food might fill you up. It doesn't mean you'll feel good about it later.

Packed with wit and warmth, "Microbe and Gasoline" is a minor key showstopper. It's proof you don't always need a huge fireworks display, sometimes a bottle rocket and a few sparklers will do the trick.
Greengrass stages three breathless marquee action sequences, including a smash-em-up car chase down the Las Vegas Strip that would make even the "Fast and Furious" gang stop and gawk.
Bundle up: "Wind River" will blow you away.
A slick, smarter-than-your-average-bear heist comedy that moves and grooves with all the hallmarks of a Soderbergh caper. He's back, baby.
Director Amanda Lipitz takes viewers home with the students and creates palpable drama around their quests to attend college following their senior year.
It's an odd mixture of Sunday church and comics that probably should have chosen one or the other.
The clumsy script has difficulty establishing the rules of what the doll and the daughter can do, so you're never really sure of what the characters are up against.
It's not so much harrowing as it is repetitive, and the film gets stuck in a single gear it can't get itself out of.
It's an unexpectedly radical, if otherwise rather rote animated sequel.
movie_title: The Nut Job 2: Nutty by Nature (2017)

movie_review_blurb: "Kidnap" was shot in 2014 and has been sitting on the shelf for two years. Frankly, it should have stayed missing.
Snipes, for his part, looks bored off his rocker. He barely gets to move, and spends most of the movie looking like he's making to-do lists in his head.

Gore is seen on the phone and in meetings with various figures, pushing toward a goal of saving the planet. "The Avengers" do it with intergalactic battles, Gore does it with an iPhone and a global travel itinerary.
movie_title: An Inconvenient Sequel: Truth To Power (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Pugh is a wrecking crew, communicating pure malevolence with a simple glance, but always keeping her composure. She may be evil, but she's first and foremost a lady.
"A Ghost Story" is an oddly haunting, wholly original trip.
The way it detonates off the screen makes the film live up to its name. It's atomic, and it's a blast.

It hurts, because it needs to. This is not a film about civic pride or the city's comeback. We have to own this, and Bigelow highlights this ugly moment on its 50th anniversary. Yes, the city has moved on, but this incident still stings.
It's an extraordinary undertaking, and Nolan delivers a spellbinding ride. Out of the depths or man-made horror, he's created a gripping tale of human resolve.
"Whose Streets?" doesn't pretend to solve any problems, only illuminate those that are happening everyday. It's a documentary that lives and breathes in the here and now.
"Menashe" is a little slice of life, delivered with a knowing sense of truth.
"Brigsby Bear" is the kind of movie Kyle Mooney would make fun of on "Saturday Night Live."
"The Hitman's Bodyguard" comes at you hard, but skates by on its charms. Kiss kiss, bang bang.
Overstuffed, over-busy and overlong, "Kingsman: The Golden Circle" is an exhausting, patience-trying assault that doesn't know when to say when.
"Friend Request" is less insightful than a tossed off status update. Request denied.
Hittman paints with a delicate brush, and gets a strong performance out of newcomer Dickinson, who gives Frankie a soft soul beneath his chiseled physique.
"American Assassin" is bogged down by its contrived, empty-headed script (credited to four screenwriters and less than the sum of its parts) and its macho chest beating.
It's a tough nut to crack, but it's a trip to trying to break it open. Exclamation point earned.

While the killer clown Pennywise is the center of the film's marketing campaign, the image on the film's poster, it's the kids in this surprisingly robust adaptation of Stephen King's novel who give "It" its center.
Kormakur sets an icy tone from the beginning and sticks to it as his tense morality tale plays out.
The dynamic between the four friends leaps off the screen and makes "Girls Trip" a journey well worth taking.
Coogan and Brydon ... begin to grate, and come off as obnoxious, both to themselves and to the patrons around them, who hopefully got comped for their meals.
Take "8 Mile" and cross it with "Hustle & Flow" and add a little bit of "Precious" and you have "Patti Cake$," a hip-hop underdog story about finding the rhythm by following your own beat.
If this is New York's "Only Living Boy," the city's in more trouble than its characters are even aware.
movie_title: The Only Living Boy in New York (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The subjects are worthy of praise and "Sidemen" gives them their shine. As Perkins says when picking up his first Grammy at age 97, "better late than never."
"Ingrid Goes West" is a sharp, insightful modern day stalker fantasy, "Single White Female" through a Valencia Instagram filter.
An animated fairytale that adheres to formula, but manages to stick its landing.
Pattinson's performance is one of the year's finest and a revelation for anyone who has wanted to pigeonhole him as an actor.
"Bushwick" is an uncompromising film that makes the most of whatever budget constraints it was filmed under and has a from-the-ground-up realism that makes it almost uncomfortable to watch.
"Crown Heights" plows forward, steely in its resolve, and forgoes the emotional fireworks in favor of subdued, straightforward storytelling.
You come away admiring the effort while lamenting the execution, but swinging and missing is always better than not swinging at all.
movie_title: Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The momentum peters out by the end, but by then its job is already done. "The Little Hours" is good for some big laughs.
An oddly affecting love story about burying the hurt and trudging forward in the face of pain and finding your own version of happiness.
It has its moments, but mostly it feels like being stuck in the backseat on a long car ride.
"Megan Leavey" works because it takes Leavey seriously as a character, and it studies her journey through her life and through the Marines before Rex is even a factor in the story.

Midway through "It Comes at Night" you might wonder where it's headed, and it seems Shults may have asked himself the same question. It's a breathless thriller that will leave you gasping until it finally runs out of air itself.

Kurtzman does a decent job with the film's tone, keeping it light and humorous, but the only thing at stake seems to be the future of the Dark Universe, which means more to Universal's bottom line than it does to modern audiences.
A strong cast, including Topher Grace, Anthony Michael Hall, Alan Ruck, Ben Kingsley, Meg Tilley and Scoot McNairy round out the impressive ensemble and help this satire land its blows.
Cox's Churchill wields his cigar with the might of a baseball bat, huffing and puffing like a dragon. But in the end, "Churchill" is just blowing smoke.
Tyrnauer uses a ton of archival footage to tell his story, and brings it in at a brisk 92 minutes.
movie_title: Citizen Jane: Battle for the City (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Good mysteries are only worth solving if the set-up leaves you craving answers, and "My Cousin Rachel" doesn't beg to be unlocked. It's easy to leave behind.
It will make adults and kids chuckle openly and often.
movie_title: Captain Underpants: The First Epic Movie (Captain Underpants) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: "When you remember something," one of the group members says at one point, "it's because your spirit is in it." And there's plenty of spirit kicking around inside "Buena Vista Social Club: Adios."
What you've got is some basic R-rated humor, a few funnies, some tanned, toned bodies and a half-baked plot - nothing more, but maybe a little less. It's "Baywatch." What did you expect?
"The Fault in Our Stars" meets "Room" in "Everything, Everything," a confounding psychological drama masquerading as a cutesy teen love story.
"The Lovers" keeps folding, changing and evolving, but stays to its central theme, exploring two uncomfortably real characters who can't get out of the way of each other or themselves.
"Diary of a Wimpy Kid: The Long Haul" is the common type of road trip movie, the one where everything that can go wrong does go wrong.
movie_title: Diary Of A Wimpy Kid: The Long Haul (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The first "Alien" had better special effects. Watch it instead.
Like Coltrane's music, the sheer brilliance of his musicianship cuts through the clutter.
movie_title: Chasing Trane: The John Coltrane Documentary (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Wonder Woman has action, humor and heart, as well as strong performances across the board, especially from Gadot and Pine.
"Stronger" is tough and hard and ultimately resilient, just like the story it's telling.
"Cars 3" hums along the track, and while its heart and humor could use minor tune-ups, it does enough visually to earn a checkered flag and keep this franchise from the scrapheap - for now, at least.
It's about imperfections and dealing with the moment, and how the aftermath of death helps shape the way we handle life.
"First Kill" is a clunker; its first and only casualty is the audience's common sense.
The best summer blockbuster in years, a smart, thoughtful, confrontational and challenging allegory for a world run amok.
movie_title: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Only the most loyal of Bell buffs need apply, everyone else would be better off sticking to her Wikipedia entry.
"The Journey" has fun playing make believe, but its execution cheapens history and distills fundamental ideological differences into treacly teachable moments.
For cheap horror thrills, you can wish for better, but you can do much worse.
"The Big Sick" has a big heart and shows there are still corners left to explore in romantic comedies; it just takes someone willing to find them.
"Starless Dreams" is a heartbreaking and humanistic look at broken lives and lost hope.
Seeing Whelan move with grace and elegance across the stage is as much storytelling as you need, but this all access documentary paints a full portrait and explains her importance in the field.
Fanning, Dunst and the on-a-roll Kidman all seem ready to dive in, but "The Beguiled" stops them short. There's plenty of cunning boiling beneath the surface, but Coppola keeps a tight lid on it.

[Baby Driver] is very savvy about pop music and pop culture, and it has a number of thrilling car chase sequences. But those are side items, not main courses, and you can't put dessert before the meal. It winds up driving in circles.
"Beatriz at Dinner" is an insanely heavy-handed liberal fantasy that both sides of the aisle can come together to equally hate.
Stoner comedies serve a very specific audience, but that designation doesn't mean they have to be slapdash, lazy films.
The script around him doesn't do Elliott or the character justice, and is a missed opportunity at a late-in-life comeback role for the one-time Western star.
Transformers: The Last Knight is a punishing, pummeling experience.
It's as much a snapshot of a screwball neighborhood as it is a loose-ended shaggy dog story, with a weird, buoyant spirit that lifts it up over its somewhat sloppy storytelling.
movie_title: Once Upon a Time in Venice (2017)

movie_review_blurb: "Rough Night" is a dismal, excruciating experience, a tired retread of raunchy comedy tropes that can't be bothered to come up with any funny or original bits.
"Despicable Me 3" has some laughs, but not enough to prop up what feels like a flagging franchise.
Ritchie, using a rollicking soundtrack and wild visual flourishes, is off his rocker here, enough so that he makes a familiar, stale tale seem fresh.
movie_title: King Arthur: Legend Of The Sword (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Stiller is in prime form here, smart and self-pitying in a way that's quintessentially his own.
"44 Pages" winds up feeling like an infomercial for "Highlights," something new employees would watch on their first day at the office.
If this is indeed the end for Day Lewis, it is a fitting final bow. It's a treat to watch him drink your milkshake one last time.
If you have kids, take them. If you have nieces and nephews, take them. If you don't have kids but just want to feel like one yourself, go see it. Paddington is a bear for all seasons.
The people deserve the truth and not to be lied to, but "The Post" shows that is easier said than done, and it's harder than just writing a story and sending it to the presses.
"Hostiles" leaves a mark, and Bale gives the kind of smoldering performance that he's used to delivering. In a heavy film, he brings the weight.
"I, Tonya" turns her tragedy into triumph.
If you've seen one "Insidious," you've seen them all.
"Father Figures" is what happens when you throw a comedy and the laughs forget to show up.
Little people. Big ideas. Massive misfire.
This swan song is in serious need of some Auto-Tune.
The time-hopping, globe-trotting story is well-paced and well-acted, and timely in its portrait of greed and the way it can choke one's soul.
movie_title: All the Money in the World (2017)

movie_review_blurb: "Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle" makes the original "Jumanji" look like a towering cinematic achievement.

"The Shape of Water" is director Guillermo del Toro's finest film, a lovely, empathetic tribute to Old Hollywood, monster movies, outsiders and love that could only come from the mind of the visionary filmmaker.
Allen, 82, has his ups and downs, and while there have been more downs than ups lately he is always worth the benefit of the doubt. But "Wonder Wheel" is a ride to nowhere.
The Last Jedi works on several levels, but most importantly it's a rip-roaring good time. That's what Star Wars fans want the most, and that's what they get with this dynamite installment.
"The Disaster Artist" is a sweet, emotionally engaging tribute to friendship, the movies and the importance of dreams.
The skeletal, B-movie plotting is supposed to be self-propelling, but "The Commuter" is too ridiculous to get by on its own momentum.
You can't knock it for false advertising.
"Proud Mary" is a flawed shoot-em-up whose heart may be in the right place, but its head is nursing a gaping wound.
"Forever My Girl" is barely a step above a Lifetime movie.
Griffin, showing an easygoing charisma and sharp comic timing, is a slam dunk. Otherwise "The Female Brain" is mindless.
"Early Man" is lovingly crafted down to the smallest detail. But its story, a farcical tribute to the early origins of soccer, isn't nearly as sturdy as its presentation.
Bening finds the shattered beauty in Grahame, the tragedy of an ex-star hanging on for dear life to her waning looks and fame that has long since passed her by.
movie_title: Film Stars Don't Die in Liverpool (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It is modern, sharp and cool, honoring the past as well as the present, and pushing the boundaries of the genre past what audiences are used to from superhero movies.
There are good laughs along the way, but they're clobbered to death by Gluck's insistence that you acknowledge them.
The fastest turnaround from must-see event to disappointing dud in history.
It shows that even in the most hostile of situations, with all of our prejudices in front of and behind us, we're still in this together.
"Darkest Hour" is a one man show for Oldman. And what a show it is.
There are unintentional laughs in the plodding, clunky story, but the biggest laugh is the one this series has had on the audience for three movies.
"Faces Places" is a lively, fun, stirring tribute to art and its ability to touch people and bring souls together.
Teen lit will be back, but "The Death Cure" is lost in a maze of its own design.

Kenney and Beard are friends and business partners who experience the ups and downs of their creative partnership, but like many things in "A Futile and Stupid Gesture," their relationship feels like a glossy version of the truth.
An enlightening journey with plenty to say about music, history and the ways music can help make history.
"12 Strong" does its best to tell a story of heroism from a dark chapter in our history, but its reality is much more complicated.
There are enough nice touches and details along the way - including Clifton Collins Jr. as an old school R&B-loving pimp - to make up for its shortcomings.
[An] absorbing Slovak-Czech drama ...
Just who is "Bilal" for?
movie_title: Bilal: A New Breed of Hero (2018)

movie_review_blurb: Levine and Van Soest are on top of their subjects with a startling familiarity and shoot in such a clean, unfiltered style that at times you question if they're working from a script or if their subjects are actors.
"Last Flag Flying" is about the lies we tell ourselves, the lies the government tells us, the fights we fight and how they all inform the memories we mold.
This version of events tends to over-explain the inspiration behind the story, undermining the genius of Dickens as an author.
Playground snowball fights have more suspense and intrigue than "The Snowman," the most puzzlingly bad movie of the year.
It's one of the most effective, honest portraits of childhood you'll ever see, and a touching, poignant snapshot of American life in 2017.
Director Joseph Kosinski puts the brotherhood of the unit front and center, emphasizing the bonds forged over sweat and soot. He directs with a sense of duty to honor the crew, and he does the job.
You have to think there are better ways to tell the story of Marshall, his life and his climb to the land's highest court, but those details are left to post-script notes.
It rather clumsily explores the kinky roots of the female superhero and the thinly veiled bondage overtones at her story's core.
Like a bag of money in the woods, you should leave this movie alone.
It relies on forced exposition to push the story forward and often recalls bad dinner theater, and is certainly the least interesting way to tell van Gogh's tale.
Garfield and Foy do standout jobs of bringing honesty and realism to their roles, but "Breathe" often suffers from sucking in too much air.
A rich drama about parental ties, parental scars and getting on with life.
There's a bigger obstruction here than the mountain between the characters: it's the story that can't get out of the way of itself.
It takes on the themes and universe set forth in the original and builds on them, and manages to live up to the massive expectations that greet it. This is no replicant, it's the real deal.
"My Little Pony: The Movie" won't disrupt the Best Animated Feature category at next year's Oscars (despite any potential Brony protests), but for a message of friendship, you can do a lot worse.

Kate and Laura Mulleavy ... give everything the hazy feel of a nearly forgotten dream. They have a knack for creating and sustaining a heavy mood, but that mood is overburdened by the questions that surround the narrative.
The story at times feels too wild, too crazy to be true, but that's what makes it worth telling. "American Made" is a real whopper.
Slick and fun, "Battle of the Sexes" is an ace.
Whether "Victoria & Abdul" holds up to historical scrutiny is up for debate - the prologue says the film is "based on true events... mostly" - but Dench, as always, is the real deal.
More than anything, it's a tribute to Stanton, who wore each of his 91 years in the deep crevasses on his long face, in his weathered voice and on his frail frame.
Five Foot Two offers an intimate look at Gaga behind the scenes and beyond the fame.
Are there any Mark Felts left, and when will they stand up? "Mark Felt" is asking that question just as much as it's honoring its subject, but it's not telling anyone to hold their breath.
movie_title: Mark Felt: The Man Who Brought Down the White House (2017)

movie_review_blurb: As stiff and rigid as two equals signs, "Equals" is a bland sci-fi romance that is as dull as its scrubbed-clean visual aesthetic.
It's a credit to Washington's rock solid performance that we care as much as we do.
In the end, it's all too much, yet at the same time not enough. Despite its efforts, Coco can't rise above mid-tier Pixar.
Kaufman was a button-pusher, he sought to get a rise out of people and questioned where performance ended and real life began. "Jim & Andy" carries on that spirit. Kaufman would be proud.
movie_title: Jim & Andy: The Great Beyond - Featuring a Very Special, Contractually Obligated Mention of Tony Clifton (2017)

movie_review_blurb: "Lady Bird" is a deeply accomplished debut, as much a love letter to Gerwig's hometown as it is to awkward adolescence. It flies.
"Wonder" could easily be played for tears or easy sentimentality, but Chbosky finds the reality of the situation much more wondrous. You will, too.
"Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri" is a powder keg of rage and raw emotion that deftly dances on the line between dark comedy and wrenching drama.

At least at two hours -- brief by modern superhero standards -- Justice League doesn't overstay its welcome. But like most all-star games, it's better as fantasy than it is reality. Level your expectations to the league minimum.
"Kill Me Please" is a bold, vivid exploration of adolescence and budding sexuality, set against a backdrop of looming fear and dread.
Aims for whimsical, but lands well short of its goal.
"Mayhem" is a frantic, blood-splattered, rock 'n' roll action-horror-comedy that plays like a killer cross between "Crank" and "Office Space."
"Ragnarok" is supposed to play for laughs, but it feels like the joke is on the audience.
The holiday season has barely started and already we have our first lump of coal.
"Thank You for Your Service" tells an important story but is pedestrian in its telling. Vets deserve a better thank you.
Lanthimos' style is sure to infuriate some viewers, but that's the point. Good or bad, he wants you to feel something, and with "Sacred Deer," oh boy, he hits his mark.
movie_title: The Killing of a Sacred Deer (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Somewhere in this interestingly shot mystery there's an exploration of identity, masculinity and marital discord, but those themes are obscured by the sublime, strange Blake Liveliness of it all.
Curtis drags the story through all the routine period motions, where everybody looks and talks and dresses like they're in a stately prestige film.

A lot of remakes of Hollywood classics trip over themselves to appeal to modern day crowds, but Branagh is a classicist at heart. In front of and behind the camera, he makes this journey a throwback ride worth taking. All aboard.
This is a smart, gritty, quietly chaotic war movie which resonates far beyond its purposely small scale.
"Suburbicon" wants to say something about us, today, but it can't get the words right. It can't even get the language right. It's as marble-mouthed as its title.
There's plenty of access to Assange, but not much insight to his person. Who is he? Why does he believe so deeply in his convictions?
It hums along, but it's standard issue action stuff, and the first "Jack Reacher" taught us to expect more than that.
This story is best left on the page.

"A Madea Halloween" is rare for Perry in that it's one of only two "Madea" films not adapted from a stage play, but it sure feels like one, with several scenes ... feeling like a one-act, one-room play that goes on and on and on.
movie_title: Tyler Perry's Boo! A Madea Halloween (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Galifianakis and Hamm are better than the material here, but they do what good actors in okay movies are supposed to do, they make it rise to them.
"What Now?" is packed with laughs. What's missing is a little bit of heart.
Hare's screenplay (based on Lipstadt's book) is smart and engaging, and veteran director Mick Jackson ("The Bodyguard") treats the material with the heft it deserves.

At nearly three hours, "American Honey" is the most indulgent movie of the year, and the one in most need of a serious trim. It makes its point early on and then keeps repeating it until the honey turns sour.
Feels like a total misfire from top to bottom.
Despite a cringe-worthy gaffe with regards to the Wu-Tang Clan's geographical origins, "Middle School: The Worst Years of My Life" is harmless fun with a trace of anarchy in its DNA.
movie_title: Middle School: The Worst Years of My Life (2016)

movie_review_blurb: "Generation Startup" has lofty goals, but its reach is overextended.
The cast, especially Blunt and Bennett, turn in fine, layered performances, and keep the "Train" on its tracks. Even if you know the story already, it's well worth the ride.
"The Birth of a Nation" aims for the gut and hits its target. Had it aimed a little higher, it might also have hit the mind, as well.
There's plenty to admire here, especially if your taste is tailored to the unusual.
"Deepwater Horizon" makes its intentions clear and does its job, just like the workers aboard that rig.
In the past, Burton has shown he does peculiar better than anybody. This time around, his touch is as useless as a mouth in the back of your head.
movie_title: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It's a tiptoe of a movie, but it's as elegant and graceful as the vast Montana landscape.

The Detroit rockers may not have been "the greatest rock and roll band ever," as the movie declares in its thesis statement, but Jarmusch treats the group as such, which is what you want from a celebration of a band.
You don't need a hidden set of clues to decipher that "Inferno" is one of the worst movies of the year.
"Supersonic" captures the madness of Oasis from an insider's perspective.
LaBeouf ... ably carries "Man Down" on his shoulders. He has an easy, natural chemistry with Shotwell, and he's a reservoir of buried emotions in his scenes with Oldman.
There's a boyish charm to Beatty's performance, and the film maintains a whimsical, lightly zany tone throughout.
If movies are meant to be a getaway, "Moana" is like a vacation.
Writer-director Tom Ford, in his second movie (following 2009's "A Single Man"), can't connect the dots on an emotional level.
"Allied" has plenty working in its favor, but a Hollywood classic it's not. It just looks like one.
Teller is magnetic in the lead role, and he helps "Bleed for This" transcend boxing movie clichés.

Nichols is one of today's finest rural storytellers, and he never wavers in his approach, going small where others would go grandiose. "Loving" is an exercise in restraint befitting the quiet couple at its center.
In the movie, Phiona can see eight moves ahead, and "Queen of Katwe" often feels the same: You know what's coming, but it doesn't dilute the feeling of victory.
A lavish visual feast that nonetheless fails to cast any new spells over its audience.
movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It's as predictable as your aunt's holiday stuffing, but the cast finds some places to open up the material.
There's a bit of an undercurrent of "The Graduate" in "Dreamland," which plays out like a grown-up coming of age tale.
It doesn't pack the punch you'd expect from an alien invasion movie; it aims higher, and in the end, it cuts deeper.
"Trolls" isn't likely to advance mankind in any significant way, but it's a harmless adventure with a few toe-tapping musical numbers and a positive message of togetherness and teamwork.
There's a bunch of mumbo jumbo about sorcerers and whatnot, which weigh down the screenplay like an anchor.
The battle scenes in "Hacksaw Ridge" are among the most violent captured on film - and also the most urgent.
"Moonlight" is a film of rare grace - a tender, compassionate, restrained look at a life lived in the shadows.
"Edge of Seventeen" is something special. To see it is to remember what it's like to be 17, and to be grateful you're not 17 anymore.
It's painful and tragic, yet it's cut with elements of humor and laughter. Just like life.
For good-enough family fun, "Storks" delivers.
A movie about privacy that would be better off kept to itself.
It's watchable popcorn entertainment and it goes down easy, but material like this should be challenging and should at least ask a few prodding questions.
In real life, Jenkins became famous for her lack of talent. But "Florence Foster Jenkins" honors her spirit, which is more powerful than any notes on the musical scale.
Rather than a big, special effects-driven blockbuster, this remake of the 1977 Disney musical has the homespun feel of a children's book come-to-life.
"Sausage Party" is smarter than it looks at the same time as it is overly taken with its juvenile humor.
A post-script details the aftermath of the movie's action, which seems to underscore the point that war is hell. To that point, so is "Anthropoid."
"Joshy" is like a weekend with random friends: fun and familiar, but rarely any deeper than the personalities involved. Don't look for more and you'll be fine.
However many Kleenex you think you should bring, double it.
Despite its pluses, "Indignation" often plays like a heavy handed after-school special. It's not so much indignant as it is tedious.
Don't think twice, just see it.
Too much goes unsaid and too many issues are unresolved. The scenery is nice, but "Five Nights in Maine" just isn't worth the trip.
Sometimes it's good to be bad. In Suicide Squad's case, bad is just plain bad. It gives villainy a bad name.
"Nerve" is sharp looking and delivers real jolts, even if the climax pushes things a bit far and wraps up too easily. Or maybe it's an accurate look at what'll happen when "Nerve" becomes real?

Hahn hijacks the film and makes it her showcase. She's rude and crude in a physical, full-body performance, and half her lines seem improvised, because she spits them out like a spray of machine gun bullets.
If it doesn't reach the heights of Woody's best - 2013's "Blue Jasmine" was his last great film - it still has several rich touches, including a luminous performance by Kristen Stewart.
Hawn has more to offer than this, and Schumer is the right partner to bring it out of her. But "Snatched" isn't the right vehicle for them.
The cast is uniformly magnificent, but it's Pine who steals the movie.
"Kubo" is bold and daring, telling a truly unique tale set in ancient Japan that is rich with the depth of a story passed down for generations.
A shrewd tale about women on Wall Street and the glass ceiling, corruption and back-stabbings they face from their male co-workers and one another.
"Don't Breathe" is a breathless, visceral, nerve-racking thrill ride that doesn't stop coming at you until its final gasps.
"Magnificent" is pushing it, but "The Magnificent Seven" - the latest spin on the classic outlaw tale - comes in guns blazing, sweeps the town and gets the job done.
Tipping throws all sorts of tricks at the screen, most of which don't work.

Wingard was in high school when "The Blair Witch Project" came out, so he's checking something off his personal list here. Everyone else moved on from "Blair Witch," with good reason, a long time ago.
If Snowden's story wasn't real, Stone would have made it up. So why does Stone's movie feel so toothless?
Welcome back, Bridget Jones.
"The Wild Life" is an import from Belgium that should have been left at customs.
A touching story of forgiveness, acceptance and moving forward.
"Demon" is a testament to a still-budding talent, and it would have been fascinating to see where he went next.
"Sully" isn't interested in going anywhere new. Watching the movie, you can feel Eastwood hurrying up to finish to move on to his next thing.
Anya Taylor-Joy ... plays the title character with a mixture of vulnerability and detached humanity that makes her like the world's most frightening teenager.
"Morris from America" feels thin at times. But at its best, its themes of growing up, culture gaps and the power of music take the specific and make them universal.
"Kickboxer: Vengeance" isn't going to raise anyone's SAT score, but it's passable in the realms of kickboxing cinema and will hold your attention during late-night cable viewing.
A muddled, boneheaded, laughable fantasy drama that stumbles from the gate and never finds its purpose.
Van Sant seems unsure of what kind of movie he's making or what he's trying to say. It's best to just enjoy the scenery and look the other way.
"Hands of Stone" is less like a boxing flick and more like a professional wrestling battle royale with all its different subplots angling for main event status.
"Southside With You" plays like "Before Sunrise" if those two characters had a really epic epilogue.
There's real emotion and consequence in this three-hankie weepie. It earns its tears.
We don't need to like her, but Chastain makes us understand and even sympathize with her, ruthless and cunning though she may be. It's remarkable work.
Everything feels stilted and strangely flat.

A modern feminist horror tale that rewards deep exploration beneath its admittedly beautiful surface. What looks like it might be simply a pure exercise in style not only invites multiple viewings, it requires them.
This is a handsomely shot, weighty story, and Chastain is a knockout in the lead.
Ducournau, 33, is a promising, smart filmmaker with a lot to say, and "Raw" is quite a medium to present her ideas.
It's not easy to make an entire movie around a two-word premise, and "Boss Baby" shows why.
It already feels like a rerun.
"American Anarchist" is an interesting look at accountability on several different levels.
Espinosa thinks he's making "Gravity," not a SyFy movie with an unusually good cast. In space, no one can hear you sigh with resignation.
Like Wilson himself, the movie is a bit of a throwback, out-of-step with the times, but whimsical in its execution.
"The Blackcoat's Daughter" is a self-contained tale of evil that knows exactly what it's doing.
"Personal Shopper" is tough to pin down, but it's a strange and stunning ride - haunting without being hokey, with surprises around every turn.
Broadbent, so often a supporting player, is a treat in the lead role, soft and mournful, but with a youthful gleam in his eye.
Like most office Christmas parties, you should skip it.
"Kedi" is the cat's meow. Literally.
It's a tale as old as time, but in its latest imagining it still feels fresh.
A fun if muddled monster movie that gets its best jolts from the sheer size of its beasts.

Jackman's performance is Clint Eastwood-esque, and the lines in Jackman's face tell the story of his worn character; he plays Wolverine as a man at the end of his line, adding at least a decade to his 48 years.
While it's far from subtle getting there, "Before I Fall" sticks its landing in its final moments. And what could have been a forgettable teen drama leaves a lasting impression.

If there's going to be a Trainspotting sequel, T2 Trainspotting is the best case scenario. It rewards a cult-like obsession with the first film, incorporating copious visual callbacks to Trainspotting and nuggets of the original's soundtrack into its DNA.
"Table 19" is like being stuck at the worst table at a bad wedding.

You want to forgive it just because it looks so good. And you can, to a point. But like those holographic giants towering above the city, it's mostly just digital noise, visually impressive, but soulless.
Despite Kidman's best efforts, almost nothing clicks on an emotional level, and the movie passes as slowly as sand through an hourglass.
"Norman" is a small character study of a classic wannabe - think "The King of Comedy," set in the world of Jewish politics - and when it gets bogged down in international intrigue it loses its way.
movie_title: Norman (Norman: The Moderate Rise and Tragic Fall of a New York Fixer) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: There's a thin line between just enough and too much, and "Guardians Vol. 2" trips over that line and never gets back up.
"Graduation" has a lot on its mind, but is told in such an intimate way it's like eavesdropping on a conversation: the closer you listen, the more you'll hear.
For Lynch - who hasn't made a feature since 2006's "Inland Empire" - the look back is clearly edifying, as you can feel him reflecting upon his journey in between long drags on his cigarettes.

"Born in China" won't teach you everything there is to know about pandas, snow leopards or snub-nosed monkeys, and its storylines feel manipulated by the Disney machine. But darned if it doesn't make you say "aww."
An exhausting, masturbatory, self-indulgent Tarantino facsimile.
"I Called Him Morgan" works as a jazz documentary as well as a bizarre true crime tale about a mysterious crime of passion. All these years later, many questions remain.
"The Assignment" is an embarrassment all around, a murky, regrettable piece of gutter cinema. Next year's Razzie Awards race starts here.
"The Promise" should have been priority viewing, but it's all over the place, taking on the Armenian Genocide, journalism ethics, foreign diplomacy and a host of other weighty topics.
"The Void" gets louder, grosser and more stupid the further it progresses, becoming an endurance test in its final sequences.
The erotic thriller canon is littered with similar stories, and "Unforgettable" doesn't attempt to reinvent the wheel.
A life behind the lens is examined in "Cameraperson," a fascinating, purposely disjointed documentary from director Kirsten Johnson.
As biopics go, it's a bogey.
"Colossal" is a challenge, no doubt, but writer-director Nacho Vigalondo pulls it off with a visionary flourish.

If you're not interested in seeing a fleet of cars get chased across a frozen lake by a Russian submarine, that's between you and your maker. As long as you are, [Fate] is a wildly entertaining thrill ride that never lets its foot off the gas.
There are weightier movies with more moral complexity, but this is just a hug from grandpa. And who couldn't use more of those?
It's a bold journey and it's a little bonkers, but like Fawcett, "The Lost City of Z" is admirable in its resilience.
"The Shack" is a grief-packed journey through loss, bargaining and acceptance that feels like an overly long church sermon.
Even when surrounded by junk, the 83-year-old MacLaine still has plenty of pep. She's a treasure, but "The Last Word" doesn't do her or her legacy justice.
"Toni Erdmann" has plenty to say about parenting, ambition, feminism and modern happiness, but not enough to justify its absurdly longwinded running time.
It sure looks great - it was lensed by Tarantino regular Robert Richardson - and its gangster-movie tropes are familiar, yet welcome.
For those not exulted by the inner-workings of devotion, it's a slog.
Locy's good intentions and optimistic worldview take him only so far, and he struggles to find a fitting capper for his story. But the performances and the characters linger in your mind.
It keeps you guessing, if only to find out, "uh, is that all there is?"
Johnson, Vaughan and Jackson were trailblazers whose fight deserves to be heard, and "Hidden Figures" honors them by turning their story into an audience-pleaser.
Some films are a speeding train. This one is a hammock on a Saturday afternoon.
"Fences" is an effective drama, but it feels rigid, its stage origins handicapping its storytelling.
Its themes are universal. Everyone has a home, and everyone feels connected to it, no matter how far they travel.
Like "Meet the Parents," but littered with F-bombs, "Why Him?" is a holiday comedy that never quite figures itself out.
Lawrence and Pratt are both big movie stars and they look good, fulfilling the minimum requirements of holiday movie fare. But "Passengers" is a missed shot at something more worthy of their talents.
The songs are rudimentary, the animation doesn't sparkle, the story doesn't inspire.
"Jackie" is a gamble, and Portman makes it pay off.

A holiday movie with Hallmark Channel DNA that should star Jaleel White and Judith Light but somehow snagged a top-line cast that includes Will Smith, Helen Mirren, Kate Winslet, Keira Knightley and Edward Norton.
"La La Land" is a special, special experience, and movies like this don't come around too often.

Rogue One is groundbreaking for the Star Wars franchise, a rousing side story that blows the doors wide open for future installments of the series. That it stands on its own as a slam-bam action thrill ride is a bonus.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It's a story about one city, but it honors the essence of America, and it shows that when the going gets rough, we're all Boston Strong.
"Split" doesn't do enough to overcome its weaknesses, bouncing between a grungy horror exploitation flick, a psychological thriller and a supervillain origin story.

This is a tough movie that takes on adult issues and doesn't shy away from the grim realities of its subject matter. But that's what makes this grim children's story work. It's a work of lovely darkness.
Big, dumb times call for big, dumb movies, and they don't come much bigger or dumber than "xXx: The Return of Xander Cage."
Noble but stuffy, "A United Kingdom's" good intentions suffer from its dull, predictable beats.
"The Founder" is a bit like McDonald's: it's satisfying, but it leaves you hungry for more.

At 90 minutes it could have been an eerie, tricky, well-crafted thriller. At two hours its wheels start to fall off. And then it continues to limp along for another 30 minutes, after which you wonder what the point of it all was in the first place.
"Fist Fight" is so terminally unpleasant that it feels like the audience is the one catching a beating. In this fight, there are only losers.
It's meant to play to as broad an audience as possible, so everything about it is spread thin, and its attempts at humor warrant light chuckles at best.
It's the Bat-spoof we didn't know we needed and it gives Batman a chance to loosen up.
There continues to be no chemistry between department store mannequins Steele and Grey, and the world director James Foley builds around them is flat and unrecognizable as real life.
It's not exactly riveting material, and even Jim Jarmusch - the veteran writer-director who traffics in the day-to-day contemplation of human existence - struggles to make "Paterson" pop.
Writer-director Jordan Peele has fashioned a smart, scathing commentary ... as a base for his allegory on the horror of race in America.
In the wrong hands, this type of thing could be a drag, but "John Wick 2" is one of the most fun action pictures in recent memory.

It is an urgent, gut-wrenching film that doesn't sugarcoat the truth. America's race problem is all of our problem, it argues, and will not change until all of us step up and take responsibility for our role in it.
There's a big problem at the center of "The Comedian": It's not funny. At all.
"A Dog's Purpose" finds itself in a peculiar spot, pandering to dog lovers, but still not giving them what they want.
McConaughey does everything he can to make it shine, but the mine is empty.
It's a credit to Mills that he makes it feel like he's making the Earth move even when he's just capturing a snapshot in time.
"Elle" never pulls any punches, and Verhoeven titillates right until the end.
Suárez gives a searing performance in the lead role, her grief overwhelming her to the point where she physically wears it on her body.
The film is filled with good-on-paper moments that build up and slowly tighten like a knot but usually end in a whimper.
From an outsider's perspective, Died Young is thorough, diving into minor, specific details like the silkscreen process used by many of the artists.

Spread out over 33 years and framed almost entirely in three crucial, tension-filled scenes, Oliver Hirschbiegel's Five Minutes of Heaven dissects the intersection of two men's lives in the aftermath of wartime and sectarian conflict.
A mean-spirited nightmare of throwaway gags.
movie_title: The Goods: Live Hard, Sell Hard (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Armando Iannucci's debut feature In The Loop carries on the staggering comedic traditions of its source material, his critically embraced BBC series The Thick of It, hardly ever missing a step.
A vivid tale of deceitful, sexual obsession.
Dazzle reveals the crack in the walls of humanity, delicately reflecting upon man's inability to survive when emotional burden becomes too much to handle.

This fresh look at the gay culture and its desired goals establishes profound insight into what it means to be a true-to-spirit man these days, no matter if he happens to wear a little lipstick and maybe a scarf or two.

This is thoroughly a family affair, but with the Polish brothers' upcoming film Manure just around the corner, Stay Cool feels a bit rushed, suggesting nothing more than an homage to Pretty in Pink or Some Kind of Wonderful.
Playing the misogynistic, bar-hopping, impulsive, titular irritant, Campbell's thespy histrionics come off as truly labored.
Simply a case of we've-seen-this-before-and-better (at least Sandra Bullock's The Net had camp value), Conspiracy flimsily masquerades as a ticking bomb but is ultimately sans heart-pounding jolts.
Part of that restless, productive team of mumblecore savants, Swanberg allows his actors to do what they do best: act.
The taxing whimsy of Phoebe in Wonderland proves more grating than poignantly escapist.
Strictly fodder for the preteen set, Under the Sea 3D, the latest IMAX deep-sea-dive exploration (brought to you by the fisheye's point of view), is expectedly rudimentary but a splendor to watch.
The principal strength of Wassef's debut is its delicate, revealing look at Marina's life.
The documentary digs deep into the racial and monetary problems of a tumultuous, melting-pot community.
Now a 3D animated film, adapted to the screen by Phil Lord and Chris Miller, Cloudy looks to work similar magic on a new generation.
movie_title: Cloudy With a Chance of Meatballs (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The film is as insubstantial and irrelevant as the group itself, providing no probing insight into its ultimate purpose and function, or how they managed to survive all these years.
movie_title: Smile 'Til It Hurts: The Up with People Story (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Despite buoyant performances from its cast and an excellent score by Sigur Rós, cloying sentimentality is in heavy supply throughout Scott Hick's adaptation of Simon Carr's memoir.
Eckhart operates on cruise control, but the performance can't be helped as the screenplay is insincere and the overall tone of the film is inconsistent.

Trite, silly, and grating are all apt words to describe the cinematic buffoonery of Rachel Perkin's Bran Nue Dae, a flimsy excuse for a nostalgic musical that shoots for playful satire but ultimately proves staggeringly impotent.
Director Gary Lundgren's Calvin Marshall eventually falls flat in its heavy-handed efforts to score an emotional homerun.
Pretty much proffers everything you can want in a film based on the upstart company that brought porn to a computer screen near you.
At over 100 minutes, Ramona and Beezus is a hefty cinematic effort to get through, especially considering how audience-surveyed and clichéd the film proves
Red Alert overtly hammers away ideas about corrupt bureaucracy squashing the little man.
